editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it hath bin lately in Action by the Children of Paules.
LONDON, Printed by H. B. for WALTER BVRRE, and are to be ſold in Paules Church-yard, at the ſigne of the Crane. 1608.

div.stage: Enter Dick Folly-wit, and his conſorts, Lieftenant Mawe-worme, Antient Hoboy, and others his Comrades.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Captaine, Regent, Principall,

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: What ſhall I call thee?
The Noble ſparke of bounty;
The life-bloud of Society.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Call mee your Forecaſt, you whoreſons, when you come drunk out of a Tauerne, t'is I muſt caſt your plots into forme ſtil; tis I muſt manage the Pranck, or Ile not giue a louſe for the proceeding: I muſt let flie my ciuil fortunes, turne wilde-braine, lay my wits vpo'th Tenters, you raskals, to maintaine a company of villaines, whom I loue in my very ſoule and conſcience.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: A ha, our little forecaſt.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Hang you, you haue bewitcht me among you, I was as well giuen till I fell to be wicked, my Grandſire had hope of me, I went all in blacke, ſwore but a Sundaies, neuer came home drunke, but vpon faſting nights to clenſe my ſtomacke; ſl'id now I'me quite altered, blowne into light colours, let out othes by'th minute, ſit vp late till it bee early, drinke drunke till I am ſober, ſincke downe dead in a Tauerne, and riſe in a Tabacco-ſhop: her's a transformation: I was wont yet to pitie the ſimple, and leaue e'm ſome money: ſl'id, now I gull e'm without conſcience; I goe without order, ſweare without number, gull without mercie, & drinke without meaſure.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: I deny the laſt, for if you drinke nere ſo much, you drinke within meaſure.

sp.speaker: Folly-w
sp.p: How proue you that ſir?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Becauſe the drawers neuer fill their pots.

sp.speaker: Folly-w
sp.p: Maſle that was well found out all drunkerds may lawfully ſay, they drinke within meaſure by that tricke, dna now I'me put i'th mind of a tricke can you keepe your countenance villaines? yet I am a foole to aske that, for how can they keepe their countenance that haue loſt their credits?

sp.speaker: Ants.
sp.p: I warrant you for bluſhing Captaine.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: I eaſily beleeue that Antient, for thou loſt thy colours once; Nay faith as for bluſhing, I thinke ther's grace little enough amongſt you all, tis lent in your cheekes, the flag's downe; wel, your bluſhing face I ſuſpect not, nor indeed greatly your laughing-face, vnleſſe you had more money in your purſes: then thus compendiouſly now, you all know the poſſibilities of my hereafter fortunes, and the humor of my frolike Grandſire Sir Bounteous Progreſſe; whoſe death makes all poſſible to me: I ſhall haue all, when he ha's nothing; but now he ha's all, I ſhall haue nothing: I thinke one minde runnes through a million of e'm; they loue to keepe vs ſober all the while the're aliue, that when the're dead we may drinke to their healths; they cannot abide to ſee vs merry all the while the're aboue ground; and that makes ſo many laugh at their fathers funerals: I know my Grandſire has his Will in a Boxe, and has bequeath'd all to me, when he can carry nothing away; but ſtood I in neede of poore tenne pounds now, by his will I ſhould hang my ſelte e're I ſhould get it, ther's no ſuch word in his Will I warrant you, nor no ſuch thought in his mind.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: You may build vpon that Captaine.

sp.speaker: Folly w.
sp.p:
Then ſince hee ha's no will to doe me good as long as he liues; by mine owne will, Ile doe my ſelfe good before he dies, and now I arriue at the purpoſe. You are not ignorant I'me ſure, you true and neceſſary implements of miſchiefe; firſt, that my Grandſier Sir Bounteous Progreſſe is a Knight of thouſands, and therefore no Knight ſince one
thouſand ſixe hundred: next, that he keepes a houſe like his name Bounteous, open for all commers: thirdly and laſtly, that hee ſtands much vpon the glory of his complement, variety of entertainement, together with the largenes of his Kitchin, longitude of his Buttery, and fecunditie of his Larder, and thinkes himſelfe neuer happier then when ſome ſtiffe L. or great Counteſſe alights, to make light his diſhes: theſe being well mixt together may giue my proiect better encouragement, and make my purpoſe ſpring forth more fortunate: to be ſhort, and cut off a great deale of durty way; Ile downe to my Grandſire like a L.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: How Captaine?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: A French ruffe, a thinne beard, and a ſtrong perfume will doo't: I can hire blew coats for you all by Weſtminſter clocke, and that colour will be ſooneſt beleeued.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: But prethee Captaine?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Puſh, I reach paſt your fadomes; you deſire crowns.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: From the crowne of our head, to the ſole of our foot bully.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Why carry your ſelues but probably, and carry away enough with your ſelues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why there ſpoke a Romane Captaine, M. Penitent Brothell.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Sweete M. Folly-wit..

Heer's a mad braine a'th firſt, whoſe prankes ſcorne to haue preſidents; to be ſecond to any; or walke beneath any: madcaps inuentions, has plaid more trickes then the cardes can allow a man, and of the laſt ſtampe too, hating imitation, a fellow, whoſe onely glory is to be prime of the company; to be ſure of which, he maintaines all the reſt: hee's the Karion, and they the Kytes that gorge vpon him.
sp.l: But why in others doe I checke wilde paſſions,
And retaine deadly follies in my ſelfe?
I taxe his youth of common receiu'd riot,
Times Comicke flaſhes, and the fruits of blood;
And in my ſelfe ſooth vp adulterous motions,
And ſuch an appetite that I know dams me,
Yet willingly embrace it, loue to Harebraines wife,
Ouer whoſe howers and pleaſures her ſicke husband
With a fantaſticke but deſerud ſuſpect,
Beſtowes his ſerious time in watch and ward;
And therefore I'me conſtraind to vſe the meanes
Of one that knowes no meane, a Curtizan,
One poyſon for another, whom her husband
Without ſuſpition innocently admits
Into her company, who with tried art
Corrupts and looſens her moſt conſtant powers,
Making his ielouſy more then halfe a wittoll,
Before his face plotting his owne abuſe,
To which himſelfe giues ayme.
Whilſt the broad arrowe with the forked head
Miſſes his browe but narrowly; ſee here ſhe comes,
The cloſe Curtizan, whoſe mother is her bawde.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Maſter Penitent Brothell.

sp.speaker: M.Pen.
sp.p: My litle prety Lady gull-man, the newes, the comfort?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Y'are the fortunate man ſir, Knight a'th holland skirt: there wants but opportunitie and ſhee's waxe of your owne faſhioning, ſhe had wrought her ſelfe into the forme of your loue before my art ſet finger to her.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Did our affections meete? our thoughts keepe time?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: So it ſhould ſeeme by the muſicke, the onely iarre is in the grumbling baſe violl her husband.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Oh his waking ſuſpition!

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Sigh not M. Penitent, truſt the managing of the buſines with me, tis for my credite now to ſee't well finiſh't: if I do you no good ſir, you ſhall giue me no money ſir.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: I am arriu'd at the Court of conſcience; A Curtizan! O admirable times! honeſtie is remoued to the Common place. Farewell Lady.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: How now daughter?

sp.speaker: Curtiz,
sp.p: What newes mother?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: A token from thy keeper.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Oh from ſir Bounteous Progreſſe: hee's my keeper in deed, but ther's many a peece of veniſon ſtolne that my keeper wots not on; theres no parke kept ſo warily, but looſes fleſh one time or other; and no woman kept ſo priuately, but may watch aduantage to make the beſt of her pleaſure: and in common reaſon one keeper cannot be enough for ſo proud a parke as a woman.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Hold thee there girle.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Feare not me mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Euery part of the world ſhootes vp daily into more ſubtilty: the very ſpider weaues her caules with more art and cunning, to entrap the flie.
sp.l: The ſhallow ploughman can diſtinguiſh now,
Twixt ſimple truth and a diſſembling browe.
Your baſe mechanick fellow can ſpy out
A weakenes in a L. and learnes to floute.
How do'ſt behooue vs then that liue by ſleight,
To haue our wits wound vp to their ſtretcht height?
Fifteene times thou knowſt I haue ſold thy may denhead,
To make vp a dowry for thy mariage, and yet
Theres may denhead enough for olde ſir Bounteous ſtil,
Heele be all his life time about it yet, and bee as far to ſeeke when he has done.
The ſummes that I haue told vpon thy pillow!
I ſhall once ſee thoſe golden daies agen:
Tho fifteene, all thy may den heads are not gone:
The Italian is not ſerude yet, nor the French:
The Britiſh men come for a dozen at once,
They ingroſſe all the market, Tut my girle,
Tis nothing but a politicke conueyance;
A ſincere carriage, a religious eyebrowe
That throwes their charmes ouer the worldlings ſenſes;
And when thou ſpieſt a foole that truely pities
The falſe ſprings of thine eyes,
And honorably doates vpon thy loue,
If he be rich, ſet him by for a husband;
Be wiſely tempered and learne this my wench
Who gets th' opinion for a vertuous name
May ſin at pleaſure, and nere thinke of ſhame:

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Mother I am too deepe a Scholler growne To learne my firſt rules now.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: T'will be thy owne, I ſay no more; peace, harke, remoue thy ſelfe, oh, the two elder Brothers.

sp.speaker: Poſſibi.
sp.p: A faire hower ſweete Lady.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Good morrow gentlemen, Maſter Ineſſe, and M. Poſsibilitie.

sp.speaker: Eſſe
sp.p: Wher's the litle ſweete Lady your daughter?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Euen at her booke ſir.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: So religious?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Tis no new motion ſir, ſh'as tooke it from an infant.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: May we deſerue a ſight of her, Lady?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Vpon that condition you will promiſe me gentlemen, to auoid all prophane talke, wanton complements, vndecent phrazes, and laſciuious courtings▪ (which I knowe my daughter will ſooner die then endure,) I am contented your ſuits ſhalbe granted.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: Not a bawdy ſillable I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Ineſſe.
sp.p: Sillable was plac'ſt there, for indeed your one ſillables are your bawdieſt words, pricke that downe.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: She may make nightwork ont, twas wel recouered, Hee Cats and Curtizans ſtrowle moſt i'th night, Her friend may be receiude and conuayde forth, nightly, He be at charge for watch and ward, for watch & ward yfaith, and here they come.

sp.speaker: Firſt,
sp.p: Giue your worſhip good euen.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Welcome my friends, I muſt deſerue your diligence in an imployment ſerious: the troth is, there is a cunning plot laid, but happily diſcouered, to robbe my houſe: the night vncertaine when, but fixt within the circle of this month: nor do's this villany conſiſt in numbers:
sp.l: Or many partners, onely ſome one
Shall in the forme of my familiar friend,
Be receiude priuately into my houſe,
By ſome perfidious ſeruant of mine owne,
Addreſt fit for the practiſe.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: O abominable!

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: If you be faithfull watchmen, ſhew your goodnes, And with theſe Angels ſhoare vp your eye-lids: Let me not be purloind, purloind indeed; the merry Greekes conceiue me: there is a Iem I would not looſe, Kept by the Italian vnder locke and key: we Engliſh men are careleſſe creatures: well, I haue ſaid enough.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: And we wil do enough ſir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Why wel ſaid, watch me a good turne now, ſo, ſo, ſo,
Riſe villany with the Larke, why tis preuented,
Or ſteal't by with the leather winged Bat:
sp.p: The euening cannot ſaue it, peace; Oh Lady Gulman, my wifes onely company! welcome; and how do's the vertuous Matron, that good old Gentlewoman thy mother? I perſwade my ſelfe, if modeſty be in the world ſhe has part on't: a woman of an excellent carriage all her life time, in Court, Citie, and Countrey.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Sha's alwaies carried it well in thoſe places ſir; witneſſe three baſtards a piece: how do's your ſweete bedfellow ſir? you ſee I'me her boldeſt viſitant.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And welcome ſweete Virgin, the onely companion, my ſoule wiſhes for her; I left her within at her Lute, prethee giue her good counſell.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Alas, ſhe needes none ſir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Yet, yet, yet, a little of thy inſtructions will not come amiſſe to her.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Ile beſtow my labour ſir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Doe, labour her prethee; I haue conuay'd away all her wanton Pamphlets, as Hero and Leander, Venus and Adonis, oh two luſhious mary-bone pies for a yong married wife, here, here, prethie take the reſolution, and reade to her a little.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Sha's ſet vp her reſolution alreadie ſir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: True, true, and this will confirme it the more, ther's a chapter of Hell, tis good to reade this cold weather, terrifie her, terrifie her; goe, reade to her the horrible puniſhments for itching wantonnes, the paines alotted for adulterie; tell her her thoughts, her very dreames are anſwerable, ſay ſo; rip vp the life of a Curtiza, & ſhew how loath ſom tis.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: The gentleman would perſwade mee in time to diſgrace my ſelfe, and ſpeake ill of mine owne function.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: This is the courſe I take, Ile teach the married man
A new ſelected ſtraine, I admit none
But this pure virgin to her company,
Puh, that's enough; Ile keepe her to her ſtint,
Ile put her to her penſion,
She gets but her allowance, thats bare-one,
Few women but haue that beſide theire owne,
Ha, ha, ha, nay Ile put her hard toote.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Faine would I meete the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Puſh, faine would you meete him, why, you doe not take the courſe.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: How earneſtly ſhee labours her, like a good holſome ſiſter of the familie, ſhe wil preuaile I hope.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is that the meanes?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: What is the meanes? I would as gladly to inioy his ſight, imbrace it as the—

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Shall I haue hearing? liſten?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: She's round with her yfaith.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: When husbands in their ranck'ſt ſuſpitions dwell,
Then tis our beſt Art to diſſemble well,
Put but theſe notes in vſe, that Ile direct you,
Hele curſe himſelfe that ere he did ſuſpect you,
Perhaps she will ſollicite you, as in triall
To viſit ſuch and ſuch, ſtill giued deniall,
Let no perſwaſions ſway you, they are but fetches
Set to betray you, Ielouſies, ſlights and reaches,
Seeme in his ſight to indure the ſight of no man,
Put by all kiſſes, till you kiſſe in common,
Neglect all entertaine, if he bring in
Strangers, keepe you your chamber, be not ſeene;
If he chance ſteale vpon you, let him find,
Some booke lie open gainſt an vnchaſt mind,
And coted Scriptures, tho for your owne pleaſure,
You reade ſome ſtirring pamphlet, and conuay it
Vnder your Skirt, the fiteſt place to lay it,
This is the courſe my wench to inioy thy wiſhes,
Here you performe beſt, when you moſt neglect,
The way to daunt, is to outuie ſuſpect,
Manage theſe principles but with Art and life,
Welcome all Nations, thou'rt an honeſt wife.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: She puts it home yfaith, eu'n to the quicke
From her Elaborate action I reach that,
I muſt requite this maide, faith Im'e forgetfull.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Here Lady, conuay my hart vnto him in this Iewel,
Againſt you ſee me next you ſhall perceiue
I haue profited, in the meane ſeaſon tel him
I am a priſoner yet, a'th maſters ſide,
My husbands ielouſie, that maſters him, as he doth maſter me,
And as a keeper that locks priſoners vp,
Is himſelfe priſon'd vnder his owne key,
Euen ſo my husband in reſtraining me,
with the ſame ward bars his owne libertie.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Ile tell him how you wiſh it, and Ile weare
My wits to the third pile, but all ſhall cleere.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I owe you more then thankes, but that I hope
My husband will requite you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Thinke you ſo Lady? he ha's ſmall reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: What done ſo ſoone? away, too't againe, too't again, good wench too't again, leaue her not ſo, where left you. come.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Faith I am wearie ſir.
I cannot draw her from her ſtrickt opinion.
With all the arguments that ſenſe can frame.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No; let me come, Fie wife, you muſt conſent; what opinion i'ſt, let's heare?

sp.speaker: Curtiz
sp.p: Fondly and wilfully ſhe retaines that thought, That euery ſinne is dambd.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Oh fie, fie, wife! Pea, pea, pea, pea, how haue you loſt your time? for ſhame be conuerted: theres a diabalocall opinion indeed; then you may think that vſury were dambd: you're a fine merchant yfaith; or briberie? you know the law well; or ſloth? would ſome of the Clergy heard you yfaith; or pride? you come at Court; or gluttony? you're not worthie to dine at an Aldermans table:
sp.l: Your onely deadly ſin's Adultery,
That villanous ring-worme, womans worſt requitall,
Tis onely lechery thats dambd to'th pit-hole;
Ah, that's an arch-offence, beleeue it ſquall,
All ſinnes are veniall but veneriall.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: I'ue ſaid enough to her.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And ſhe will be rulde by you.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Fah.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Ile pawne my credit ont; come hither Lady,
I will not altogether reſt ingratefull,
Here, weare this Rubie for thy paines and counſell.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: It is not ſo much worth ſir, I am a very ill counſellor truely.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Goo too I ſay.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Y'are too blame yfaith ſir, I ſhall nere deſerue it.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Thou haſt don't already: farewell ſweet Virgin, prethee let's ſee thee oftner.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Such gifts will ſoone intreat me.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Wife, as thou lou'ſt the quiet of my breaſt,
Embrace her counſell, yeeld to her aduices;
Thou wilt find comfort in e'm in the end;
Thou'lt feele an alteration, prethee thinke on't:
Mine eyes can ſcarce refraine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Keepe in your dewe ſir, leaſt when you would, you want it.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I'ue pawnde my credite on't, ah didſt thou know, The ſweete fruit once, thoud'ſt neuer let it goe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Tis that I ſtriue to get.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And ſtill do ſo.

div.head: Incipit Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Sir Bounteous with two Knights.

sp.speaker: Firſt,
sp.p: You haue bin too much like your name Sir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh not ſo, good Knights, not ſo, you know my humour; moſt welcome good Sir Andro Pelcut, Sir Aquitaino Colewort, moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Thankes good Sir Bounteous.

div.stage: At the other, enter in haſt a footman.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Oh, crie your worſhip heartily mercy Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now linnen ſtockins, and threeſcore mile a day; whoſe footman art thou?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Pray can your worſhip tell me, Hoh, hoh, hoh, if my L. be come in yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Thy L! what L?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My L. Owe-much ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My L. Owe-much! I haue heard much ſpeech of that L. h'as great acquaintance i'th Citie; that L. has bin much followed.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: And is ſtill ſir; he wants no company when hee's in London: hee's free of the Mercers, and theres none of e'm all dare croſſe him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: And they did, hee'd turne ouer a new leafe with e'm; he would make e'm all weary on't i'th end: much fine rumor haue I heard of that L. yet had I neuer the fortune to ſet eye vpon him; art ſure he will alight here Footman? I am afraid thou'rt miſtooke.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Thinkes your worſhip ſo ſir? by your leaue ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Puh; paſſion of me, Footman, why Pumps I
ſay come backe.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Do's your worſhip call?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come hither I ſay, I am but afraid on't, would it might happen ſo well, how do'ſt know? did hee name the houſe with the great turret a'th top?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: No ſaith did he not ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come hither I ſay, did hee ſpeake of a cloth a gold chamber?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Not one word by my troth ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come againe you lowzie ſeuen mile an houre?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I beſeech your worſhip detaine me not.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Was there no talke of a faire paire of Orgaines, a great guilt candleſticke, and a paire of ſiluer ſnuffers?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: T'were ſinne to belie my Lord, I heard no ſuch words ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A pox confine thee, come againe, puh,

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Your worſhip wil vndoe me ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Was there no ſpeech of a long dining roome, a huge kitchin, large meate, and a broad dreſſer board?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I haue a greater maw to that indeed, an't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Whome did he name?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Why one Sir Bounteous Progreſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah, a, a, I am that Sir Bounteous you progreſſiue round-about Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Laughs, puh—

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I knew I ſhould haue him i'th end, ther's not a Lord wil mis mee I thanke their good honours, tis a fortune laide vpon me, they can ſent out their beſt entertainment, I haue a kind of complementall gift giuen mee aboue ordinary country Knights, and how ſoone, tis ſmelt out I warrant yee, ther's not one Knight i'th Sheere able to entertaine a Lord i'th kue, or a Lady i'th nick like me, like me, ther's a kinde of grace belongs too't, a kind of Art which naturally ſlips from me, I know not on't I promiſe you, tis gon before Im'e aware on't, cuds mee I forget my ſelfe, where—

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Do's your worſhip call?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Run ſirrah, cal in my chief gentleman i'th chaine of gold, expedite; and how do's my good Lord? I neuer ſaw him before in my life, a cup of baſtard for this footman.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lord has trauaild this fiue yeare ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Trauaild this fiue yeare? how many children has he? ſome baſtard I ſay.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: No baſtard an't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A cup of Sack to ſtrengthen his wit, the footmans a foole; oh, come hither maſter Gunwater, come hither, ſend preſently to maſter Pheſant for one of his hens, ther's Partrige i'th houſe.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: And Wild-duck an't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: And Woodcock an't pleaſe thy worſhip.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: And Woodcock an't pleaſe your worſhip, I had thought to haue ſpoke before you.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Remember the Pheſant, downe with ſome Plouer, clap downe ſixe Woodcocks, my loue's coming; now ſir.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Ant pleaſe your worſhip ther's a Lord and his followers newly alighted.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Diſpath I ſay, diſpatch, why wher's my muſick? hee's come indeed.

div.stage: Enter Folly-wit like a Lord with his Comrades in blew coates.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Footman.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Folli.
sp.p: Run ſwiftly with my cōmendations to S. Iaſper Topas Wee'le ride and viſit him i'th morning ſay.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Your Lordſhips charge ſhal be effected.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: That Courtly comly forme, ſhould preſent to me Sir Bounteous Progreſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Y'aue found me out my Lord, I cannot hide my ſelfe, Your honour in moſt ſpatiouſly welcome.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: In this forgiue mee Sir, that being a ſtranger to your houſes,
And you, I make my way ſo bold, and preſume
Rather vpon your kindnes then your knowledge,
Onely your bounteous diſpoſition.
Fame hath diuulgd, and is to me well knowne.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Nay, and your Lordſhip know my diſpoſition, you know me better then they that know my perſon; your honor is ſo much the welcomer for that.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Thankes good ſir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, it has been often my ambition my L. both in reſpect of your honourable preſence, and the prodigall fame that keepes euen ſtroke with your vnbounded worthines;
sp.l: To haue wiſht your Lordſhip, where your Lordſhip is
A noble gueſt in this vnworthy ſeate:
Your Lordſhip nere heard my Organs.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Heard of e'm ſir Bounteous, but neuer heared e'm.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The're but double guilt my L. ſome hundred and fifty pound wilt fit your Lordſhippe with ſuch another paire.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Indeed ſir Bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O my L. I haue a preſent ſute to you.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: To me ſir Bounteous, and you could nere ſpeake at fitter time? for I'me here preſent to grant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip has been a traueller.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Some fiue yeare ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I haue a Grandchild my L. I loue him; and when I die Ile doe ſomewhat for him: Ile tel your honor the worſt of him, a wilde lad he has beene.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: So we haue beene all ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: So we haue been all indeed my L. I thanke your Lorſhips aſſiſtance; ſome comick prancks he has bin guilty of; but Ile pawne my credit for him, an honeſt truſty boſome.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And thats worth all ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: And thats worth all indeed my L. for hees like to haue all when I die; imberbis Iuuenis, his chin has no more prickles yet then a midwiues: theres great hope of his wit his haire's ſo long a comming; ſhall I be bold with your honor, to prefer this aforeſaid Ganimed to hold a plate vnder your Lordſhips cup?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You wrong both his worth, and your bountie, and you cal that boldnes; Sir I haue heard much good of that yong Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Nay h'as a good wit yfaith my L.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: H'as caried himſelfe alwaies generouſly.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Are you aduiſde of that my L.? h'as caried many things cleanely: Ile ſhew your Lordſhip my Will, I keep it aboue in an Out landiſh boxe; the whoreſon boy muſt haue all: I loue him, yet he ſhall nere find it as long as I liue.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Well ſir, for your ſake, and his own deſeruing, Ile reſerue a place for him neereſt to my ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I vnderſtand your good Lordſhip, you'le make him your Secretary: my muſicke, giue my L. a taſte of his welcome.

div.stage: Aſtraine plaid by the Conſort, Sir Bounteous makes a Courtly honour to that L. and ſeemes to foot the tune.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: So, how like you our Ayres my Lord? are they choice?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: The're ſeldome match't beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The Conſort of mine owne houſhold.

sp.speaker: Folly w.
sp.p: Yee ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The Muſitians are in Ordinary, yet no ordinary Muſitians: your Lordſhip ſhall heare my Organs now.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Oh I beſeech you ſir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My Organiſt.
sp.stage: The Organs play, and couerd diſhes march ouer the Stage.
sp.p: Come my L. how do's your honour relliſh my Organ?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: A very proud Ayre yfaith ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh, how can't chuſe, a Walloon plaies vpon e'm, and a Welchman blowes wind in their breech.

div.stage: Enter ſir Bounteous with Folly-wit, and his conſorts toward his lodging.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
You muſt pardon vs my L. haſty cates, your honor
has had eu'n a hunting meale on't; and now I am like to bring your Lordſhip to as meane a lodging, a hard Downe bed yfaith my L. poore Cambricke ſheetes, and a cloth a Tiſſue Canopy, the Curtaines indeed were wrought in Venice, with the ſtory of the Prodigall child in ſilke and golde, onely the Swine are left out my L. for ſpoyling the curtaines.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: T' was well preuented ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Silkin reſt, harmonious ſlumbers, and venetiall dreames to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: The like to kind Sir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Fie, not to me my L. I'me old, paſt dreaming of ſuch vanities.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Old men ſhould dreame beſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Their dreames indeed my L. y'aue gi'nt vs: tomorrow your Lordſhip ſhal ſee my Cockes, my Fiſh-ponds, my Parke, my Champion grounds; I keepe Champers in my houſe can ſhew your Lordſhip ſome pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Sir Bounteous you eu'n whelme me with delights.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Once agen a muſicall night to your honor; Ile trouble your Lordſhip no more.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Good reſt ſir Bounteous; ſo, come, the vizards, where be the masking ſuits?

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: In your Lordſhips Portmantua.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Peace Leiftenant.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: I had rather haue war, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Puh, the plot's ripe; come, to our buſines lad, Tho guilt condemnes, tis gilt muſt make vs glad.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: Nay, and you be at your diſtinctions Captaine, Ile follow behind no longer.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Get you before then, and whelme your noſe with your vizard, goe.
sp.l: Now Grandſire, you that hold me at hard meat,
And keepe me out at the Dags end, Ile fit you;
Vnder his Lordſhips leaue, all muſt be mine
He and his Will confeſſes, what I take then
Is but a borrowing of ſo much before hand;
Ile pay him agen when he dies, in ſo many blacks,
Ile haue the Church hung round with a noble a yard,
Or requite him in Scutchions, let him trap me
In gold, and Ile lap him in lead; quid pro quo: I
Muſt looke none of his Angels in the face forſooth,
Vntill his face be not worth looking on; Tut lads,
Let Sires and Grandſires keepe vs low, we muſt
Liue when the're fleſh, as well as when the're duſt.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Go, ſirrah, run preſently to M. Penitent Brothel; you know his lodging, knocke him vp, I know he cannot ſleepe for ſighing; tell him I'ue happily bethought a meane,
sp.l: To make his purpoſe proſper in each limbe,
Which onely reſts to be approu'd by him:
Make haſt, I know he thirſts for't.
sp.p: Within. Oh.

div.stage: Enter in a masking ſute with a vizard in his hand, Folly-wit.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Harke, the're at their buſines.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Theeues, theeues.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Gag that gaping raskall, tho he be my Grandſires chiefe Gentleman i'th chaine of gold, Ile haue no pitie of him; how now lads?

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: Al's ſure and ſafe, on with your vizard ſir; the ſeruants are all bound.

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: There's one care paſt then, come follow me lads, Ile lead you now to'th point, and top of all your fortunes; yo'n lodging is my Grandſires.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: So, ſo, lead on, on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Her's a Captaine worth the following, and a wit worth a mans loue and admiring!

div.stage: Enter with Sir Bounteous in his night-gowne.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh gentlemen, and you be kind gentlemen, what countrimen are you?

sp.speaker: Folly w.
sp.p: Linconſheere men Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I am glad of that yfaith.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And why ſhould you be glad of that?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh, the honeſteſt theeues of all come out of Linconſheere; the kindeſt naturde Gentlemen; the'le rob a man with conſcience: they haue a feeling of what they go about, and will ſteale with teares in their eies: ah pitifull gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Puſh, Money, money, we come for money.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Is that all you come for? Ah what a beaſt was I to put out my money tother day: alas good gentlemen, what ſhift ſhall I make for you? pray come agen another time.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Tut, tut ſir, money.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh not ſo loud ſir, you're too ſhrill a Gentleman; I haue a L. lies in my houſe, I would not for the world his honour ſhould be diſquieted.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Who my L. Owemuch? we haue tooke order with him before hand, he lies bound in his bed and al his followers.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Who my L? bound my L? Alas what did you meane to bind my L? he could keepe his bed well enough without binding: y'aue vndon me i'nt already, you need rob me no farder.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Which is the Key, come?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah I perceiue now, y'are no true Linconſheere ſpirits; you come rather out of Bedforeſheere, we cannot lie quiet in our beds for you: ſo, take enough my Maſters; ſpur a free horſe, my name's ſir Bounteous, a merry world yfaith; what Knight but I keepe open houſe at midnight? well, there ſhould be a conſcience, if one could hit vppon't.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Away now, ceaze vpon him, binde him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Is this your Court of equity? why ſhould I be bound for mine owne money? but come, come, bind me, I haue neede on't; I haue beene too liberall to night, keepe in my hands: nay, as hard as you liſt; I am too good to beare my L. company, you haue watcht your time my Maſters; I was Knighted at Weſtminſter, but many of theſe nights will make me a Knight of Windſor; y'aue deſerude ſo well my
Maſters; I bid you all to dinner to morrow, I would I might haue your companies yfaith, I deſire no more.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Oh ho ſir!

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Pray meddle not with my Organs, to put e'm out of tune.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Oh no, heeres better muſicke ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah pox feaſt you.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Diſpatch with him, away; ſo, thanke you good Grandſire; this was bounteouſly done of him yfaith; it came ſomewhat hard from him at firſt; for indeed nothing comes ſtiffe from an old man but money: and he may well ſtand vpon that, when he has nothing elſe to ſtand vpon: where's our Port-mantua?

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: Here Bully-Captaine.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: In with the purchaſe, t'will lie ſafe enough there vnder's noſe I warrant you: what, is all ſure?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All's ſure Captaine.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You know what followes now, one villane binds his fellowes; go, we muſt be all bound for our owne ſecurities raskals, there's no dallying' vppo'th point; you conceit me: there is a L. to be found bound in the morning, and al his followers, can you picke out that L. now?

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: O admirable ſpirit!

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You nere plot for your ſafeties, ſo your wants be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: But if we binde one another, how ſhall the laſt man be bound?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Pox on't, Ile haue the footman ſcape.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Thats I, I thanke you ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p:
The Footman of all other will be ſuppoſde to ſcape, for he comes in no bed all night; but lies in's clothes, to be firſt ready i'th morning: the horſe and he lies in litter together; that's the right faſhion of your bonny Footman: and his freedome will make the better for our purpoſe; for we muſt haue one i'th morning to vnbinde the Knight, that we may haue our ſport within our ſelues: we now arriue at the moſt tickliſh point, to rob, and take our eaſe, to be theeues and
lie by't, looker to't lads, it concernes euery mans gullet; Ile not haue the jeſt ſpoilde, that's certaine, tho it hazard a windepipe: Ile either go like a L. as I came, or be hangd like a theeſe as I am; and that's my reſolution.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: Troth a match Captaine, of all hands.

div.stage: Enter Curtizan with M. Penitent Brothel.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Oh M. Penitent Brothel!

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: What is't ſweet Lady Gulman, that ſo ſeazes on thee with rapture and admiration?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: A thought, a tricke, to make you ſir eſpecially happy, and yet I my ſelfe a ſauer by it.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: I would embrace that Lady with ſuch courage, I would not leaue you on the looſing hand.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I wil giue truſt to you ſir, the cauſe then why I raiſde you from your bed ſo ſoone; wherein I know ſighs would not let you ſleepe, thus vnderſtand it: You loue that woman (M. Harebraines wife) Which no inuented meanes can crowne with freedome, For your deſires and her owne wiſh, but this, Which in my ſlumbers did preſent it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: I'me couetous Lady.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: you know her husband lingring in ſuſpect, Lockes her from all ſociety, but mine.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Moſt true.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: I onely am admitted, yet hitherto That ha's done you no reall happines; by my admittance I cannot performe that deed, that ſhould pleaſe you, You know: wherefore thus I'ue conuaid'd it, Ile counterfet a fit of violent ſickenes.

sp.speaker: M.Pen.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Nay tis not ſo good by my faith, but to doe you good.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: And in that ſenſe I call'd it, but take me with you Lady; would it be probable enough to haue a ſickenes ſo ſuddenly violent?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p:
Puh, all the world knows women are ſoone down;
we can be ſicke when we haue a mind to't, catch an ague with the wind of our fans, ſurfet vpon the rumpe of a Larke, and beſtow ten pound in phyſick vpon't; we're likeſt our ſelues when we're down: tis the eaſieſt Art and cunning for our ſect to counterfeit ſicke, that are alwaies full of ſits when we are well; for ſince we were made for a weake imperfect creature, we can ſit that beſt that we are made for: I thus tranſlated, and your ſelfe ſlipt into the forme of a Phyſition.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: I a Phyſition Lady, talke not on't I beſeech you, I ſhall ſhame the whole Colledge.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Tutman, any guackſaluing termes will ſerue for this purpoſe; for I am pitifully hanted with a brace of elder brothers, new perfumde in the firſt of their fortunes, and I ſhall ſee how forward their purſes will be to the pleaſing of my pallat, and reſtoring of my health; lay on load enough vpon e'm, and ſpare e'm not, for the're good plump fleſhly Aſſes, and may well enough beare it: let gold, Ambre, and diſſolued Pearle, be common ingrediences, and that you cannot compoſe a culliſſe without e'm: put but this cunningly in practiſe, it ſhall bee both a ſufficient recompence for all my paines in your loue, and the readie meanes to make Miſtris Harebraine; way, by the viſiting of me to your mutuall deſired company.

sp.speaker: M.Pen.
sp.p: I Applaud thee, kiſſe thee, and wil conſtantly embrace it.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ho, Gunwater!

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Singleſtone!

sp.speaker: Within
sp.p: Ienkin, wa, ha, ho.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.p: Ewen!

sp.speaker: Within
sp.p: Simcod!

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: Footman! whewe—

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Oh good your worſhip, let me helpe your good old worſhippe.

div.stage: Enter Sir Bount, with a cord halfe vnbound, Foot with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah poore honeſt footman, how didſt thou ſcape this maſſacre?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: E'en by miracle, and lying in my clothes ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I thinke ſo, I would I had laine in my clothes to Footman, ſo I had ſcapt e'm; I could haue but riſſe like a begger then, and ſo I do now, till more money come in; but nothing afflicts me ſo much, my poore Geometricall Footman, as that the barberous villaines ſhould lay violence vpon my L. Ah, the binding of my L. cuts my heart in two pieces; ſo, ſo, tis well, I thanke thee, runne to thy fellowes, vndo e'm, vndo e'm, vndo e'm.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Alas, if my L. ſhould miſcarry, the're vnbound already ſir; they haue no occupation but ſleepe, feed, and fart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: If I be not aſhamde to looke my L i'th face, I'me a Saraſſen my L.

sp.speaker: Folly w.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: One may ſee hee has beene ſcard, a pox on e'm for their labours.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Singleſtone!

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Singleſtone? Ile nere anſwere to that yfaith.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Suchman-

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Suchman? nor that neither yfaith; I am not brought ſo low, tho I be old.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Who's that i'th chamber?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Good morrow my L. tis I.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Sir Bounteous good morrow, I would giue you my hand ſir, but I cannot come at it; is this the curteſie a'th countrie ſir Bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip grieues me more then al my loſſe; Tis the vnnatural'ſt ſight that can be found, To ſee a noble gentleman hard-bound.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Truſt me, I thought you had beene better belou'd ſir Bounteous; but I ſee you haue enemies ſir, and your friends fare the worſe for em: I like your talke better then your lodging; I nere lay harder in a bedde of Downe; I haue had a madde nights reſt on't: can you not geſle what they ſhould be Sir Bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Faith Lincolneſhire men my Lord.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: How? fie, fie, beleeue it not ſir, theſe lie not far off I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Thinke you ſo my Lord?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: I'le be burnt & they doe, ſome that vſe to your houſe ſir, and are familiar with all the couneiances.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: This is the commoditie of keeping open houſe my Lord, that makes ſo many ſhut their doores about dinner time.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: They were reſolute villaines, I made my ſelfe knowne to e'm, told e'm what I was; gaue e'm my honorable word not to diſcloſe e'm.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O ſawcie vnmannerly villaines!

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And thinke you the ſlaues would truſt me vpon my word?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: They would not?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Forſooth no, I muſt pardon e'm, they told mee Lords promiſes were mortal, and commonly die within halfe an houre after they are ſpoken; they were but griſtles, and not one amongſt a hundred come to any full groth, or perfection, and therefore tho I were a L. I muſt enter into bond.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Inſupportable Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Troth Im'e of that mind Sir Bounteous you far'd the worſe for my coming hither.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah good my Lord, but Im'e ſure your Lordſhip far'd the worſe.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Pray pittie not me ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Is not your honour ſore about the brawne of the arme? a murren meete e'm, I feele it.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: About this place Sir Bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: You feele as it were a twinge my Lord?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: I, ee'n a twinge, you ſay right.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A pox diſcouer e'm, that twinge I feele too.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: But that which diſturbs mee moſt Sir Bounteous lies here.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: True, about the wriſt, a kind of Tumid numnes.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: You ſay true Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bount.
sp.p: The Reaſon of that my Lord is, the pulſes had no play.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Maſſe ſo I geſt it.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun
sp.p: A miſchiefe ſwell e'm, for I feele that to.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: Sli'd her's a houſe haunted indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A word with you ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: How now Singleſtone?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Im'e ſorry my Lord your Lordſhip has loſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Pup, pup, pup, pup, pup.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: What haue I loſt? ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A good nights ſleepe ſay.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Speake, what haue I loſt I ſay?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: A good nights ſleepe my Lord, nothing elſe. Curtens drawn

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: That's true, my cloth's come.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: My Lords cloth's, his honor's riſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hiſt, well ſaid, come hither, what ha's my Lord loſt, tell mee, ſpeake ſoftly?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: His Lordſhip muſt know that Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Huſh, prethee tell mee.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: T'will doe you no pleaſure to know't Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Yet againe? I deſire it I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Since your worſhip will needs know't, they haue ſtolne away a iewell in a blew ſilke riband of a hundred pound price, beſide ſome hundred pounds in faire Spur-Royals.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: That's ſome two hundred it'h totall.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Your worſhip's much about it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come follow me, Ile make that whole againe in ſo much money, let not my Lord know on't.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Oh pardon me Sir Bounteous, that were a diſhonor to my Lord, ſhould it come to his eare, I ſhould hazard my vndoing by' it.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How ſhould it come to his eare? if you be my Lords chiefe man about him, I hope you do not vſe to ſpeake, vnles you be paid for't, and I had rather giue you a Councellors double Fee to hold your peace, come, go too, follow me I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: There will be ſcarce time to tell it ſir, my Lord wil away inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: His honour ſhall ſtay dinner by his leaue', I'le preuaile with him ſo far; and now I remember a leſt; I bad the whoreſon theeues to dinner laſt night, I would I might haue their companies, a pox poyſon e'm.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Faith and you are like to haue no other gueſſe Sir Bounteous, if you haue none but vs, I'le giue you that gift yfaith.

div.head: Incipit Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Maſter Harebraine with two elder brothers, Maſter Ineſſe, and Maſter Poſſibilitie.

sp.speaker: Poſſibi.
sp.p: YOu ſee bould gueſts Maſter Hareb.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: You'r kindly welcome to my houſe; good Maſter Ineſſe, and Maſter Poſſibilitie.

sp.speaker: Ineſſe
sp.p: That's our preſumption Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Rafe?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Call downe your miſtris to welcome theſe two Gentlemen my friends.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I will obſerue her carriage, and watch The ſlipperie reuolotions of her eye, Ile lie in waite for euery glance ſhe giues, And poyze her words it'h ballance of ſuſpect, If ſhe but ſwag ſhee's gon, either on this hand Ouer familiar, or this, too neglectfull, It do's behoue her carry her ſelfe euen.

sp.speaker: Poſſibi.
sp.p: But maſter Hareb.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: True, I heare you ſir; wa'ſt you ſaid?

sp.speaker: Poſſibi.
sp.p: I haue not ſpoke it yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Right, ſo I ſay.

sp.speaker: Poſſibi.
sp.p:
Is it not ſtrange, that in ſo ſhort a time, my little
Lady Gulman ſhould be ſo violently handled?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Oh, ſicknes has no mercy ſir,
It neither pitties Ladies lip, nor eye,
It crops the Roſe out of the Virgins cheeke,
And ſo deſlowres her that was nere deſlorw'd,
Fooles then are maides to locke from men that treaſure,
Which death will plucke, and neuer yeeld e'm pleaſure;
Did you not heare her gentlemen, it'h midſt
Of her extreameſt ſit, ſtill how ſhe cald vpon my wife,
Remembred ſtill my wife, ſweet miſtris Harebraine,
When ſhe ſent for me, a one ſide of her bed ſtood the Phiſitian,
the Scriuener on the other, two horrible obiects, but,
meere oppoſites in the courſe of their liues, for the Scriuener
bindes folkes, and the Phiſitian makes them looſe.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: But not looſe of their bonds Sir?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No by my faith ſir, I ſay not ſo, if the Phiſitian could make e'm looſe of their bonds, ther's many a one would take Phiſick, that dares not now for poyſoning, but as I was telling of you, her Will was faſhioning, Wherein I found her beſt and richeſt Iewell, Giuen as a Legacie vnto my wife, When I read that, I could not refraine weeping, well of all other, my wife ha's moſt reaſon to viſit her, if ſhee haue any good nature in her, ſhee'le ſhew it there, now ſir wher's your miſtris?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: She deſires you, and the gentlemen your friends, to hold her excuſed, ſha's a fit of an Ague now vpon her, which begins to ſhake her

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Where do's it ſhake her moſt?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: All ouer her body Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Shake all her body? t'is a ſaucie fit, Im'e iealous of that Ague, pray walke in gentlemen, Ile ſee you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Now they are abſent ſir, tis no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.l: My miſtris has her health Sir,
But tis her ſute, ſhe may confine her ſelfe
From ſight of all men, but your owne deere ſelfe Sir,
For ſince the ſicknes of that modeſt Vergin
Her onely company, ſhe delights in none;

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No; viſit her againe, commend me to her, Tell her they'r gon, and onely I my ſelfe Walke here to exchange a word or two with her.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Ile tell her ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Foole that I am, and madman, beaſt! what worſe?
Suſpitious or'e a creature that deſerues
The beſt opinion, and the pureſt thought,
Watchfull or'e her that is her watch her ſelfe,
To doubt her waies, that lookes too narrowly
Into her owne defects; I, fooliſh-fearefull
Haue often rudely, out of giddie flames
Bard her thoſe obiects which ſhee ſhuns her ſelfe,
Thrice I'ue had proofe of her moſt conſtant temper,
Come I at vnawares by ſtealth vpon her,
I find her cercled in with Diuine Writs
Of heauenly meditations; here and there
Chapters with leaues tuckt vp, which when I ſee
They either taxe pride or adulterie,
Ah let me curſe my ſelfe, that could be iealous
Of her whoſe mind no ſinne can make rebellious.
And here the vnmatched comes, now wife yfaith they'r gon,
Puſh, ſee how fearefull tis, will you not credit me?
sp.p: They'r gon yfaith, why, hinke you Ile betray you? come, come, thy delight and mine, thy onely vertuous friend, thy ſweete inſtructreſſe is violently taken, grieuous ſicke, and which is worſe, ſhe mends not.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Her friends are ſorry for that Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Shee cals ſtill vpon thee, poore ſoule, remembers thee ſtill, thy name whirles in her breath, wher's miſtris Harebraine ſayes ſhee?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Alas good ſoule,

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p:
She made me weepe thrice, ſh'as put thee in a iewel
in her Will.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Eee'n tot'h laſt gaſpe a kind ſoule.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Take my man, goe, viſit her.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Pray pardon me ſir, alas my viſitation cannot helpe her.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Oh yet the kindnes of a thing wife; ſtill ſhe holds the ſame rare temper; take my man I ſay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would not take your man ſir, tho I did purpoſe going.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: No? thy reaſon?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: The worlds condition is it ſelfe ſo vild Sir,
Tis apt to iudge the worſt, of thoſe deſerue not,
Tis an ill-thinking age, and do's apply
All to the forme of it owne Luxurie,
This cenſure flies from one, that, from another,
That man's her Squire, ſayes he; her Pimpe, the tother,
Shee's of the ſtampe, a third, fourth, I ha knowne her:
Iu'e heard this, not without a burning cheeke:
Then our attires are taxt, our very gate
Is cal'd in queſtion, where a husbands preſence
Scatters ſuch thoughts, or makes e'm ſinke for feare
Into the hearts that breed e'm, nay ſurely if I went Sir,
I would entreat your company.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Mine? prethee wife, I haue beene there alreadle.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: That's all one; altho you bring mee but to'th doore Sir, I would intreat no farther.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Thu'rt ſuch a wife; why I will bring thee thither then, but not goe vp I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Yfaith you ſhall not, I doe not deſire it ſir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Why then content.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Giue me your hand you will doe ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Why ther's my lip I will.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Why then I goe Sir.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: With me or no man, incomparable ſuch a woman. Exeunt.

div.stage: Viols, Gallipots, Plate, and an Houre-glaſſe by her. The Curtizan on a bed, for her counterfeit fut. To her, Maſter Penitent Brothell, like a Doctor of Phiſick.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: Lady?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Ha, what newes?

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: Ther's one Sir Bounteous Progreſſe newly alighted from his footecloth, and his Mare waites at doore, as the faſhion is.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Sli'd, 'tis the knight that priuately maintaines mee, a little ſhort-olde. ſpinye Gentleman, in a great dublet.

sp.speaker: M. Peni
sp.p: The ſame, I know e'm.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Hee's my ſole Reuenew, meate, drinke, and rayment; my good Phiſitian worke vpon him, Im'e weake.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: Ynough.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why, where bee theſe Ladies? theſe plump ſoft delicate creatures? ha?

sp.speaker: M. Peui.
sp.p: Who would you viſit ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Viſit, who? what are you with the plague in your mouth?

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: A Phiſitian ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Then you are a looſe-liuer Sir, I haue put you to your purgation.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: But you need none, you'r purg'd in a worſe faſhiō,

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Ah, Sir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now? what art thou?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Sweet Sir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Paſhion of me, what an alteration's here? Roſamond ſicke old Harry? her's a ſight able to make an olde man ſhrinke, I was luſty when I came in, but I am downe now yfaith, mortalitie, yea? this puts mee in mind of a hole ſeauen foote deepe, my graue, my graue, my graue, hiſt, maſter Doctor a word ſir, harke, tis not the Plague? iſt?

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: The Plague Sir, no?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: He ne're askes whether it bee the Poxe or no, and of the twaine that had beene more likely.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now my wench? how do'ſt?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Huh, weake Knigh, huh.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: She ſaies true, hee's a weake Knight indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Where do's it hold thee moſt, wench?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: All parts alike Sir.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: Shee ſayes true ſtill, for it holds her in none.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Harke in thine eare, thou'rt breeding of yong bones, I am afraid I haue got thee with child yfaith.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I feare that much ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh, oh, if it ſhould, a yong Progreſſe when al's done.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: You haue done your good will Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I ſee by her, tis nothing but a ſurfet of Venus yfaith, and tho I bee old, I haue gin't her, but ſince I had the power to make thee ſicke, Ile haue the purſe to make thee whole, that's certaine; maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Lets heare I pray, what i'ſt you miniſter to her?

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: Marry Sir, ſome pretious cordiall, ſome coſtly refocillation, a compoſure comfortable and reſtoratiue.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I, I, that, that, that.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: No poorer ingrediences then the liquor of Currall, cleere Amber, or Succinum, Vnicornes horne ſixe grains, Magiſterium, Perlarum one ſcruple.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: Oſſis de Corde Cerui halfe a ſcruple, Aurum Potabile or his tincture.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Very pretious Sir.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: All which being finely contunded, and mixed in a ſtone or glaſſe morter, with the ſpirit of Diamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Nay pray be patient Sir.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: That's impoſſible, I cannot bee Patient and a Phiſition too Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh, crie you mercy, that's true Sir.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: All which aforeſaid.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I, there you left Sir.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: When it is almoſt exſiccate or drie, I adde thereto olei Succini, olei Maſi, & Sinamoni.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: So Sir, olei Maſi, that ſame oyle of Maſe is a great comfort to both the Counters.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: And has beene of a long time Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Well, bee of good cheere wench, ther's gold for
thee; huh, let her want for nothing M. Doctor, a poore kinſewoman of mine, nature bindes me to haue a care of her; there I guld you M. Doctor: gather vp a good ſpirit wench, the fit will away, tis but a ſurfet of griſtles: ha, ha, I haue ſitted her; an old Knight and a cocke a'th game ſtill, I haue not ſpurs for nothing I ſee.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: No by my faith, the're hatcht, they coſt you an Angell ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Looke to her good M. Doctor, let her want nothing, I'ue given her enough already, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: So, is he gone?

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Hee's like himſelfe gon.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Heer's ſomewhat to ſet vp with; how ſoone he tooke occaſion to ſlip into his owne flattery, ſoothing his own defects; he onely feares he has done that deed, which I nere feard to come from him in my life, this purchaſe came vnlookt for.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: H'iſt, the paire of ſonnes and heires.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Oh, the're welcome, they bring money.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: M. Doctor.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: I come to you Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: How do's ſhe now?

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Faith much after one faſhion ſir.

sp.speaker: Ineſſ.
sp.p: There's hope of life ſir.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: I ſee no ſignes of death of her.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: That's ſome comfort; will ſhe take any thing yet?

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, ſhee'le take ſtill: ſh'as a kind of facility in taking: how comes your band bloody ſir?

sp.speaker: Ineſſ.
sp.p: You may ſee I met with a ſcab ſir.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Diuerſa genera Scabierum, as Pliny reports, there arediners kind of Scabs.

sp.speaker: Ineſſ.
sp.p: Pray lets heare e'm ſir.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p:
An itching ſcab, that is your harlot; a ſore ſcab, your vſurer; a running, your promooter; a broad ſcab, your intelligencer; but a white ſcabbe, that's a ſcald knaue and a
Pander: but to ſpeake truth, the onely ſcabs wee are now a daies troubled withall, are new officers.

sp.speaker: Ineſſe.
sp.p: Why now you come to mine ſir, for Ile be ſworne one of them was very buſie about my head this morning, and he ſhould be a ſcab by that, for they are ambitious and couet the head.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: Why you ſaw I deriu'de him ſir?

sp.speaker: Ineſ.
sp.p: You Phyſitions are mad Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: We Phyſitions ſee the moſt ſights of any men liuing, you're Aſtronomers looke vpward into'th aire, we look downeward into'th bodie, and indeed wee haue power vpward and downeward.

sp.speaker: Ineſ.
sp.p: That you haue yfaith ſir.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Lady, how cheere you now?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: The ſame woman ſtill, huh.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.p: That's not good.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Little alteration, Fie, fie, you haue beene to lauiſh Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ineſ.
sp.p: Puh, talke not of that Lady, thy health's worth a million; here M. Doctor, ſpare for no coſt.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Looke what you find there ſir.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: What doe you meane gentlemen, put vp, put vp, you ſee I'me downe and cannot ſtriue with you, I would rule you elſe; you haue me at aduantage, but if euer I liue, I will requite it deepely.

sp.speaker: Ineſſ.
sp.p: Tut an't come to that once, wee'le requit our ſelues well enough.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Miſt. Harebrain, Lady, is ſetting forth to viſit you too.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Hah, huh.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: There ſtrucke the munit that brings forth the birth of all my ioyes and wiſhes; but ſee the iarre now, how ſhall I rid theſe from her?

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.p: Pray gentleman, ſtay not aboue an houre from my ſight.

sp.speaker: Ineſ.
sp.p: S'foot we are not going Lady.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Subtilly brought about, yett' will not doe, the'le ſticke by't; a word with you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: What ſaies M. Doctor?

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: She wants but ſetling of her ſenſe with reſt, one howres ſleepe gentlemen would ſet all parts in tune.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: He ſaies true yfaith.

sp.speaker: Ineſ.
sp.p: Get her to ſleepe M. Doctor, wee'le both ſit heere and watch by her.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Hels Angels watch you, no Art can preuaile with e'm; what with the thought of ioyes, and ſight of croſſes, my wits are at Hercules pillars, non plus vltra.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: M. Doctor, M. Doctor?

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Here Lady.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Your phyſicke workes, lend me your hand.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Farewell ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Ineſ.
sp.p: Adue M. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.l: Let me admire thee,
The wit of man, wanes and decreaſes ſoone,
But womens wit is euer at ful moone.
There ſhot a ſtar from heauen,
I dare not yet behold my happines.
The ſplendor is ſo glotious and ſo piercing.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Miſtris Harebraine, giue my wit thankes hereafter, your wiſhes are in ſight, your opportunity ſpatious.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you but heare a word from mee?

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Whooh—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My husband himſelfe brought mee to'th doore, walkes below for my returne; ielouſie is prick-eard, and will heare the waging of a haire.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Piſh, y' are a faint-liuer, truſt your ſelfe with your pleaſure, and me with your ſecurity, go.

sp.speaker: M. Pen
sp.p: The fulnes of my wiſh.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Of my deſire.

sp.speaker: M. Pen.
sp.p: Beyond this ſphere I never will aſpire.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: Ile liſten, now the fleſh drawes nie her end,
At ſuch a time women exchange their ſecrets,
And ranſack the cloſe corners of their hearts;
What many yeares hath whelm'd, this houre imparts.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Pray ſit downe, there's a low ſtoole, good Miſtris Harebraine, this was kindly done; huh giue me your hand; huh, alas how cold you are: eu'n ſo is your husband, that worthy wiſe Gentleman; as comfortable a man to woman in my caſe, as euer trod—huh—ſhooe leather, loue him, honour him, ſticke by him, hee lets you want nothing, that's fit for a woman; and to be ſure on't, he wil ſee himſelfe that you want it not.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: And ſo I doe yfaith, tis right my humour.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: You liue a Ladies life with him, go where you will, ride when you will, and do what you will.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Not ſo, not ſo neither, ſhee's better lookt to.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I know you doe, you need not tell me that; t'were ee'n pity of your life yfaith, if euer you ſhould wrong ſuch an innocent gentleman; fie Miſtris Harebraine, what doe you meane? come you to diſcomfort mee? nothing but weeping with you?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Shee's weeping, t'as made her weepe, my wife ſhewes her good nature already.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Still, ſtill weeping? huff, huff, huff, why how now woman? hey, hy, hy, for ſhame leaue; ſuh, ſuh, ſhe cannot anſwere me for ſnobbing.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: All this do's her good, beſhrew my heart and I pity her, let her ſhed teares till morning; Ile ſtay for her, ſhe ſhall haue enough on't by my good will; Ile not be her hinderance.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: O no, lay your hand here Miſtris Harebraine: I there, Oh there, there lies my paine good gentlewoman: ſore? Oh I, I can ſcarce endure your hand vppon't.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Poore ſoule, how ſhee's tormented.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I eate a Culliſſe an houre ſince.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: There's ſome comfort in that yet, ſhe may ſcape it.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Oh it lies about my heart much.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I'me ſory for that yfaith, ſhee'le hardly ſcape it.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Bound, no, no, I'de a very comfortable ſtoole this morning.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I'me glad of that yfaith, that's a good ſigne, I ſmell, ſhee'le ſcape it now.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Will you be going then?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Fall backe, ſhee's comming.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Thanks good Miſtris Harebraine, welcome ſweet Miſtris Harebraine, pray commend me to the good gentleman your husband.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: I could do that my ſelfe now.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: And to my vncle Winchcombe, and to my Aunt Lipſalue, and to my coſen Falſetop, and to my coſen Lickit, and to my coſen Horſeman, and to all my good coſens in Clearken well, and Saint Ioneſes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: At three daies end my husband takes a iourney.

sp.speaker: M. Pent.
sp.p: Oh thence I deriue a ſecond meeting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: May it proſper ſtill, Till then I reſt a captiue to his will: Once agen health, reſt, and ſtrength to thee ſweete Lady: farewell, you witty ſquall; good M. Doctor haue a care to her body if yous ſtand her friend, I know you can doe her good.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: Take pity of your waiter, goe: farewell ſweete Miſtris Harebraine.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Welcome ſweete wife, alight vpon my lip, neuer was hower ſpent better.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why, were you within the hearing ſir?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.l: I that I was yfaith, to my great comfort; I deceiud you there wife, ha, ha;
I doe intreat thee, nay coniure thee wife
Upon my love, or what can more be ſaid?
Oftner to viſit this ſicke vertuous maid.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Be not ſo fierce, your will ſhalbe obaide.

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Why then I ſee thou lou'ſt me.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.l: Art of Ladies.
When plots are ee'n paſt hope, and hang their head,
Set with a womans hand, they thriue and ſpread.

div.stage: Enter Folly-wit with Lieftenant Maw-worme, Antient Hoboy, and the reſt of his conſorts.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Waſt not wel manag'de, you neceſſary miſchiefs? did the plot want either life or Art?

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: Tw's ſo well Captaine, I would you could make ſuch another Muſſe at all aduentures.

sp.speaker: Folly w.
sp.p: Do'ſt cal't a Muſſe? I am ſure my Grandſire nere got his money worſe in his life, then I got it from him, if euer he did cozen the ſimple; why I was borne to reuenge their quarrell; if euer oppreſſe the widdow? I, a fatherles child haue done as much for him; and ſo tis through the world either in ieſt or earneſt, let the vſerer looke for't, for craft recoyles in the end, like an ouercharg'd musket, and maymes the very hand that puts fire too't; there needs no more but a Vſurers owne blow to ſtrike him from hence to hell, twil ſet him forward with a vengeance; but here lay the ieſt whoreſons, my Grandſire thinking in his conſcience that wee had not rob'd him ynough or'e night, muſt needs pittie mee it'h morning, and giue me the reſt.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds in faire Roſe-Nobles I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Puſh, I knew he could not ſleep quietly til he had pay'd me for robing of him too, tis his humour, & the humor of moſt of your rich men in the courſe of their liues; for you know, they alwaies feaſt thoſe mouthes that are leaſt nedie, and giue them more, that haue too much alreadie; and what call you that, but robing of themſelues a Courtlyer way; Oh.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Cuds me, how now Captaine?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: A cold fit that comes ouer my memory, and has a ſhrode pull at my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: What's that Sir?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Is it for certaine, Lieftenant, that my Grandſire keepes an vncertaine creature, a Queane?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: I that's too true Sir.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.l: So much the more 'prepoſterous for mee, I ſhall
hop ſhorter by that tricke; ſhe carries away the thirds at leaſt;
twill proue en-tayld land I am afraid when al's done, yfaith
nay, I haue knowne a vicious-old-thought-acting Father,
Damb'd onely in his dreames, thirſting for game,
(When his beſt parts hung downe their heads for ſhame,)
For his blancht harlot diſpoſſeſſe his ſonne,
And make the pox his heire, twa's grauely done:
How had'ſt thou firſt knowledge on't Lieftenant?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Faith from diſcourſe, yet all the pollicie That I could vſe, I could not get her name.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Dull ſlaue that ne're could'ſt ſpie it.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: But the māner of her coming was deſcrib'd to me.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: How is the manner prethee?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Marry ſir ſhe comes, moſt commonly coacht.

sp.speaker: Folly w.
sp.p: Moſt commonly coacht indeed, for coaches are as common now adayes, as ſome that ride in e'm, ſhee comes moſt commonly coacht.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: True, there I left ſir, guarded with ſome leaſh of Pimps.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Beſide the coachman?

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Right ſir, then alighting, ſhee's priuatly receiu'd by maſter Gunwater.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: That's my Grandſires chiefe Gentleman it'h chaine of gold, that hee ſhould liue to bee a Pander, and yet looke vpon his chaine and his veluet iacket

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Then is your Grandſire rounded it'h eare, the key giuen after the Italian faſhion, backward, ſhe cloſly conuaid into his cloſet, there remaining, till either opportunitie ſmile vpon his credit, or hee ſend downe ſome hot caudle to take order in his performance.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Peace, tis mine owne yfaith, I haa'te.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: How now Sir?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Thankes, thankes to any ſpirit, That mingled it mongſt my inuentions.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Why maſter Folly-wit?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Captaine?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.l: Giue me ſcope and heare me,
I haue begot that meanes which will both furniſh me,
And make that queane walke vnder his conceit.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: That were double happines, to put thy ſelfe into money and her out of fauour.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And all at one dealing?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: S'foot I long to ſee that hand plaid,

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And thou ſhalt ſee't quickly yfaith; nay tis in graine, I warrant it hold colour: Leiftenant, ſtep behind yo'n hanging; if I miſtooke not at my entrance, there hangs the lower part of a gentlewomans gowne, with a maske and a chinclout; bring all this way: Nay, but doo't cunningly now, tis a friends houſe, and I'de vfe it ſo, ther's a taſt for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But prethee what wilt thou doe with a Gentlewomans lower part?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Why vſe it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Y'aue anſwered me indeed in that, I can demand no farder.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Well ſaid Leiftenant.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: What will you do now ſir?

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: Come, come, thou ſhalt ſee a woman quickely made vp here.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: But that's againſt kind Captaine, for they are alwaies long a making ready.

sp.speaker: Folly-w.
sp.p: And is not moſt they doe againſt kind I prethee? to lie with their Horſe-keeper, is not that againſt kind? to weare half moons made of anothers haire, is not that againſt kind? to drinke downe a man, ſhe that ſhould ſet him vp, pray is not that monſtrouſly againſt kind now? nay ouer with it Leiftenant, ouer with it, euer while you liue put a womans clothes ouer her head: Cupid plaies beſt at blind-man buff.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: You ſhal haue your will maintenance, I loue madde trickes as well as you for your heart ſir; but what ſhift will you make for vpper bodies Captaine?

sp.speaker: Fol.
sp.p: I ſee now thou'rt an Aſſe, why I'me ready.

sp.speaker: Leift.
sp.p: Ready?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p:
Why the Doublet ſerues as well as the beſt, and is
moſt in faſhion, weere all Male tot'h middle, mankinde from the Beuer to'th Bum, tis an Amazonian time, you ſhall haue women ſhortly treade their husbands; I ſhould haue a couple of Locks behind, prethee Lieutenant find em out for me, and wind 'em about my hatband, nay you ſhall ſee, weele be in faſhion to a hayre, and become all with probability, the moſt muſty-viſage Critick ſhall not except againſt me.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Nay ile giue thee thy due behind thy backe, thou art as mad a piece of Clay—

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Clay! doſt call thy Captaine Clay? indeede clay was made to ſtop holes, he ſayes true; did not I tell you raſcalls you ſhould ſee a woman quickly made vp?

sp.speaker: Antient.
sp.p: Ile ſweare for't Captaine.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Come, come, my maſke and my chin-cloute—Come into'th Court.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Nay they were both 'ith Court long agoe ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Let me ſee, where ſhall I chuſe two or three for Pimps now? but I cannot chuſe amiſſe amongſt you all, thats the beſt; well, as I am a Queane, you were beſt haue a care of me, and guard me ſure, I giue you warning before hand, tis a monckie taylde-Age. Life, you ſhall goe nye to haue halfe a douzen blythe fellowes ſurprize me cowardly, carry me away with a payre of owers, and put in at Putney.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: We ſhould laugh at that yfaith.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Or ſhoote in vppo'th coaſt of Cue.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Two notable fit landing places for Leachers, P. and C. Putney and Cue.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Well, ſay you haue faire warning on't, the hayre about the hat is as good as a flag vppo'th pole at a common Playhouſe to waſt company, and a chin-cloute is of that powerfull a traction I can tell you, twill draw more Linnen toot?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Feare not vs Captaine, there's none here but can fight for a whore as well as ſome Innes a Court-man?

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Why then ſet forward; and as you ſcorne two ſhilling brothell, twelue penny Pandariſme, and ſuch baſe bribes, guard me from bonny Scribs, and bony Scribes.

sp.speaker: Left
sp.p: Hang 'em, penſions, and alowancces, foure pence halfe penny a meale, hang 'em.

div.head: Incipit Actus Quartus.
div.stage: Enter in his chamber out of his ſtudie, Master Panitent, Once, Ill, a Booke in his hand reading.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.l: Ha? reade that place agen,—Adulterie
Drawes the Diuorce twixt heauen and the ſoule!
Accurſed man that ſtandſt diuorſ't from heauen,
Thou wretched vnthrift, that haſt playd away
Thy Eternall portion at a minutes game,
To pleaſe the fleſh, haſt blotted out thy name:
Where were thy nobler meditations buſied?
That they durſt truſt this body with it ſelfe,
This naturall drunkard that vndoes vs all,
And makes our ſhame apparant in our fall.
Then let my bloud pay fort, and vex and boyle,
My ſoule I know would neuer grieue tot'h death,
The Eternall ſpirit that feeds her with his breath:
Nay I that knew the price of life and ſinne,
What Crowne is kept for continence, what for luſt?
The end of man, and glory of that end
As endleſſe as the giuer:
To doat on weakneſſe, ſlime, corruption, woman?
What is ſhe, tooke aſunder from her clothes?
Being ready, ſhe conſiſts of hundred peeces,
Much like your German cloak, and nere allyed
Both are ſo nice, they cannot goe for pride.
Beſide a greater fault, but too well knowne,
Theyle ſtrike to ten, when they ſhold ſtop at one;
Within theſe three daies the next meeting's fixt,
If I meet then, hell and my ſoule be mixt.
My lodging I know conſtantly, ſhe not knowes,
Sins hate is the beſt guift that ſin beſtowes:
Ile nere embrace her more,—neuer—better witneſſe, neuer.

div.stage: Enter the Diuell in her ſhape, claps him on the ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: What at a ſtand? the fitter for my company?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Celeſtiall ſouldiers guard me,-

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: How now man? Laſe did the quickneſſe of my preſence fright thee?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Shield me you miniſters of faith and grace.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: Leaue, leaue, are you not aſhamd to vſe ſuch words to a woman?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Th'art a Deuill.
