sp.speaker: Suc.
sp.p: A diuell? feele, feele man, has a diuell fleſh and bone?

sp.speaker: Maſt Pae.
sp.p: I do coniure thee by that dreadfull power—

sp.speaker: Suc.
sp.l: The man has a delight to make me tremble;
Are theſe the fruits of thy aduenturous Loue?
Was I entiſſt for this? to be ſoone reiected?
Come, what has changd thee ſo, Delight;

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.p: Remember.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Leaue my ſight.

sp.speaker: Suc.
sp.l: Haue I this meeting wrought with cunning.
Which when I com̄e I finde thee ſhunning?
Rowze thy amorous thoughts and twine me,
All my intereſt I reſigne thee:
Shall we let ſlip this mutuall hower,
Comes ſo ſeldome in her power?
Wher's thy lip, thy clip, thy fadome?
Had weomen ſuch loues. would't not mad 'em?
Art a man? or doſt abuſe one?
A Loue! and knowſt not how to vſe-one?
Come, ile teache thee—

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pa.
sp.p: Do not follow.

sp.speaker: Succubus.
sp.l: Once ſo firme and now ſo hollow?
When was place and ſeaſon ſweeter?
Thy bliſſe in ſight and dar'ſt not meete her?
Wher's thy courage youth and vigor?
Loues beſt pleaſde, whent's ſeard with rigour:
Ceare me then with veynes moſt chearefull,
Weomen loue no fleſh that's fearefull;
Tis but a ſit, come Drinck't away,
And dance and ſing, and kiſſe and play—Fa le
La, le la, Fa le la, le la la; Fa le la, fa la le
La le la.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Paen.
sp.p: Torment me not.

sp.speaker: Succu.
sp.p: Fa le la, fa le la, fa la la, loh.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Fury.

sp.speaker: Succu.
sp.p: Fa le la, fa le la, fa la la loh.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.l: Deuill! I do coniure thee once againe,
By that ſoule-quaking thunder to depart,
And leaue this chamber, freed from thy dambd Art.

sp.speaker: Succu.
sp.p: Stamps—

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: It ha's preuayld—Oh my ſin-ſhaking Sinewes! what ſhould I thinke? Ieſper, why Ieſper.

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: Sir! how now? what has diſturbed you ſir.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: A ſit, a qualme, —is miſtriſſe Hargraue gone?

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: Who ſir? miſtriſſe Hargraue?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Is ſhe gone I ſay?

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: Gone? why ſhe was neuer here yet.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: Why no ſir.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Art ſure ont.

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: Sure ont? if I be ſure I breathe, and am my ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: I like it not; —where kepſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: It'h next roome ſir.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Why ſhe ſtruck by thee man.

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: Youde make one mad ſir, that a gentlewoman ſhould ſteale by me and I not heare her, ſfoote, one may heare the ruſling of their bums almoſt an hower before we ſee 'em.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.l: I will be ſatisfide,—altho to hazard,
What though her husband meete me? I am honeſt;
When mens intenes are wicked, their guilt haunts em,
But when they're iuſt, they're armd, and nothing daunts 'em.

sp.speaker: Ieſper.
sp.p: What ſtrange humour call you this? he dreames of weomen and both his eyes broad open!

stage.hi: Enter at one doore Sir Bounteous, at another Gum-water.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why how now maſter Gumwater? what's the newes with your haſt?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: I haue a thing to tell your worſhip —

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why prethee tell me, ſpeake man.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Your worſhip ſhall pardon me, I haue better bringing vp then ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir. Boun.
sp.p: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Tis a thing made fit for your Eare ſir —

sp.speaker: Sir. Boun.
sp.p: Oh—o—o—cry you mercy, now I begin to taſte you,— is ſhe come?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Shee's come ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun
sp.p: Recouerd, well and ſound agen?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: That's to be feard ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why ſir?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: She weares a Linnen cloth about her Iawe,

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ha, ha, haw,—why that's the faſhion you whorſon Gumwater.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: The faſhion ſir? liue I ſo long time to ſee that a faſhion, which rather was an Embleme of diſprayſe, It was ſuſpected much in Mounſiers dayes.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I, I, in thoſe dayes, that was a queaſie time, our age is better hardned now, and put oftner in the fire, we are tryed what we are: tut, the Pox is as naturall now, as an Ague in the Spring time, we ſeldome take phyſicke without it; here, take this key, you knew what dueties belong too't, goe,—giue order for a Cullize, let there be a good fire made it'h matted chamber, do you heare ſir?—

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: I know my office ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: An old mans venery is very chargeable my maſters, there much cooquery belongs too't.

div.stage: Enter Gumwater with Follywet in Curtizans diſguize, and maskt.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Come Lady, you know where you are now?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Yes, good maſter Gumwater.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: This is the old cloſet you know.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I remember it well ſir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: There ſtands a Casket, I would my yearely reuenue were but worth the wealth thats lockt int Lady; yet I haue fifty pound a yeere wench.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Beſide your apparrell ſir?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Yes faith haue I.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: But then you recken your chaine ſir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: No by my troth doe I not, neither: faith and you conſider me rightly ſweet Lady, you might admit a choyſe gentleman into your ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Oh, pray away ſir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Puſha come, come, you do but hinder your fortunes yfaith, I haue the command of all the houſe, I can tell you, nothing comes intot'h kitchin, but comes through my hands.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Pray do not handle me ſir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Faith y'are too nice Lady: and as for my ſecrecy you know I haue vowd it often to you.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Vowd it? no, no, you men are fickle,—

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Fickle?—ſfoote bind me Lady —

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why I bind you by vertue of this chayne to meet me to morrow at the Flowredeluce yonder, betweene Nine and Ten.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: And if I do not Lady let me loſe it, thy loue and my beſt fortunes?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why now ile trye you, goe too.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Farewell ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p:
Welcome ſweete cockſcombe; by my faith a good induction, I perceiue by his ouerworne phraſe, and his action toward the middle region ſtill there has bin ſome ſaucy nibling motion, and no doubt the cunning queane waited but for her prey, and I thinke tis better beſtowd vpon me for his ſoules health;—and his bodies too; ile teache the ſlaue to be ſo bould yet, as once to offer to vault into his maſters ſaddle yfaith: Now Casket, by your leaue, I haue ſeene your outſide oft, but
thats no proofe. Some haue fayre outſides that are nothing worth: ha? —now by my faith a gentlewoman of very good parts, Diamond, Rubie, Saphire, Onix cum prolo Silexque; if I doe not wonder how the queane ſcapte tempting, I'me an Hermophrodite, ſure ſhe could lack nothing, but the Diuell to poynt too't, and I wonder that he ſhould be miſſing; well, tis better as it is, this is the fruite of old-grunting-venerie. Grandſire, you may thanke your Drab for this; oh fye, in your crinckling dayes Grandſire, keepe a Curtizan to hinder your Grandchild, tis againſt Nature yfaith, and I hope youle be weary ont: Now to my villaines that lurke cloſe below: Who keepes a Harlot tell him this from me, He needes nor theeſe, diſeaſe, nor enemy.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah ſirrah, me thinke I feele my ſelfe well toſted, bumbaſted, rubd and refreſht; but yfaith I cannot forget to thinke how ſoone ſickneſſe has altered her—to my taſt, I gaue her a kiſſe at bottome o'th ſtayres, and byth maſſe me thought her breath had much adoe to be ſweet, like a thing compounded me thought of wine, Beere, and Tobacco, I ſmelt much Pudding in't. It may be but my fancy, or her phyſicke: For this I know, her health gaue ſuch content, The fault reſts in her ſickneſſe, or my ſent. How doſt thou now ſweete girle, what well recouerd? Sickneſſe quite gone, ha? ſpeake—ha? wench? Franke Gulman, why body of me, whats here? my Casket wide open, broke open, my Iewells ſtolne—why Gumwater—

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Anon anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Come hither Gumwater.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: That were ſmall manners ſir yfaith, ile find a time anon your worſhip's buſie yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why Gumwater?

sp.speaker: Gum
sp.p: Fo nay then youle make me bluſh yfaith ſir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Where's this Creature?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: What creature iſt you'de haue ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The worſt that euer breathes.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Thats a wild Bore ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: That's a vilde whore ſir;—where didſt thou leaue her Raſcall?

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Who? your Recreation ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My Execration ſir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: Where I was wont, in your worſhips cloſet.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun
sp.p: A pox engroſſe her, it appeares too true, See you this Casket ſir.

sp.speaker: Gum.
sp.p: My chayne, my chayne, my chayne, my one and only chayne.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Thou runſt to much purpoſe now, Gumwater, yee? Is not a Queane ynough to anſwer for, but ſhe muſt ioyne a theefe too't, a theeuing Queane, Nay I haue done with her yfaith, tis a ſigne ſh'as beene ſicke a late, for ſhee's a great deale worſe then ſhe was, by my troth I would haue paund my life vpon't, did ſhe want anything? was ſhe not ſupply de?
sp.l: Nay and liberally, for thats an olds mans ſinne,
Weele feaſt our Lechery, though we ſtarue our kin.
Is not my name Sir Bounteous, am I not expreſt there?
Ah fie, fie, fie, fie, fie, but I perceiue
Tho ſhe haue neuer ſo compleate a friend,
a ſtrumpets loue will haue a waſt i'th end,
and diſtaſt the veſſell: I can hardly beare this;
But ſay I ſhould complaine, perhaps ſhe has pawnd 'em,
Sfoote the Iudges will but laugh at it, and bid her borrowe
more money of em, make the old fellow pay for's lechery,
thats all the mends I get, I haue ſeene the ſame Cafe tryed at
Newbery the laſt Sizes.
Well, things muſt ſlip and ſleepe, I will diſſemble it,
becauſe my credit ſhall not looſe her luſtre,
But whilſt I liue, ile neyther loue nor truſt her.
I ha done, I ha done, I ha done with her yfaith.

div.stage: Maſter Paenitent Once-Ill-knocking within; enter a Seruus.

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: Who'ſe that knocks?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: Whats your will ſir?

sp.speaker: Ma. Pae.
sp.p: Is maſter Hargraue at home?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: No, newly gone from it ſir.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Where's the gentlewoman his wife?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: My miſtriſſe is within ſir.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: When came ſhe in I pray?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: Who my miſtriſſe? ſhe was not out theſe two dayes to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: No? truſt me Ide thought I'de ſeene her, I would requeſt a word with her.

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.p: Ile tell her ſir.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: I thanke you—It likes me worſe and worſe.—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why how now ſir? twas deſperately aduenturd, I little lookt for you vntill the morrow.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: No? why what made you at my chamber then euen now?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I at your chamber?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Puh—diſſemble not, come, come, you were there.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By my life you wrong me ſir.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Firſty' are not ignorant what watch keeps o're me, And for your chamber, as I liue I knowt not.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Burſt into ſorrow then, and greeſes extreames, Whilſt I beate on this fleſh.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What iſt diſturbs you ſir?—

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Then was the diuell in your likeneſſe there.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.l: The very Deuill aſſumde thee formally,
That face, that voyce, that geſture, that attire,
Een as it ſits on thee, not a pleate alterd,
That Beuer band, the colour of that Periwig,
The Farthingale abone the Nauill, all;
As if the faſhion were his owne inuention,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Mercy defend me.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.l: To beguile me more.
The cunning Succubus told me that meeting
Was wrought a purpoſe by much wit and Art,
Wept to me, laide my vowes before me, vrgd me,
Gaue me the priuate markes of all our Loue,
Wood me in wanton and effeminate rimes,
And ſung and danſt about me like a Fayry,
And had not worthier cogitations bleſt me,
Thy forme and his enchantments had poſſeſt me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What ſhall become of me my owne thoughts doome mee.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.l: Be honeſt; then the Diuell will nere aſſume thee,
He has no pleaſure in that ſhape to abide,
Where theſe two ſisters raigne not, luſt of pride;
He as much trembles at a conſtant mind
As looſer fleſh at him,—be not diſmayde:
Spring ſoules for ioy, his policies are betrayde;
Forgiue me miſtriſſe Hargraue, on whoſe ſoule
The guilt hangs double,
My luſt and thy enticement: both I challenge,
And therefore of due vengeance it appeard
To none but me to whome both ſins inher'd;
What knowes the lecher when he clips his whore
Whether it be the Diuell his parts adore:
They're both ſo like, that in our Naturall ſence,
I could diſcerne no change nor difference.
No maruell then times ſhould ſo ſtretch and turne
None for Religion, all for pleaſure burne.
Hot zeale into hot luſt is now tranſformde,
Grace into paynting, charity into clothes,
Faith into falſe hayre, and put off as often,
Theres nothing but our vertue knowes a meane,
He that kept open houſe now keepes a Queane.
He will keep open ſtill, that he commends,
And there he keeps a table for his friends:
And ſhe conſumes more then her Sire could hoord,
Being more common then his houſe or boord:
Liue honeſt, and liue happy, keep thy vowes,
Shees part a Virgin whom but one man knowes:
Embrace thy husband, and beſide him none,
Hauing but one heart, giue it but to one.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I vow it on my knees, with teares true bred
No man ſhall euer wrong my husbands bed.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Riſe, I'me thy friend for euer.

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.l: And I thine
For euer and euer,—Let me embrace thee ſir, whome I will
loue, euen next vnto my ſoule, and thats my wife,
Two deere Rare Iems this hower preſents me with,
A wife thats modeſt, and a friend thats right,
Idle ſuſpect and feare, now take your flight.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: A happy inward peace crowne both your ioyes

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.p: Thankes aboue vtterance to you, —now? the newes?

sp.speaker: Seruus.
sp.l: Sir Bounteous Progreſſe ſir,
Inuites you and my miſtriſſe to a feaſt,
On Tueſday next; his man attends without—

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.l: Returne both with our willingneſſe and thanks.
I will intreate you ſir, to be my gueſt.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Who I ſir.

sp.speaker: Harg.
sp.p: Faith you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Well, ile break ſtrife.

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.p: A friend's ſo rare, ile ſooner part from life.

div.stage: Enter Follywit, the Curtizan ſtriuing from him.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What ſo coy, ſo ſtrickt, come, come.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pray change your opinion ſir, I am not for that vſe.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Will you but heare me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I ſhall heare that I would not.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p:
Sfoote this is ſtrange, I'ue ſeldome ſeene a wench Stand vpon ſtricter points, life ſhe will not endure to be courted, do's ſhe ere thinke to proſper? Ile nere beleeue that Tree can bring foorth fruit, that neuer beares a bloſſome, Courtſhips a bloſſome, and often brings foorth fruit in forty weeks; Twere a mad part in me, now to turne ouer: if euer there were
any hope on't, tis at this inſtant, ſhall I be madder now then euer I haue beene? 'ime in the way ifaith.
sp.l: Mans neuer at hie height of madnes full,
Vntill he loue and proue a womans gull;
I doe proteſt in earneſt I nere knew
At which end to begin to affect a woman,
Till this bewitching minute, I nere ſaw
sp.p: Face worth my obiect, till mine eie met hers, I ſhould laugh and I were caught yfaith, Ile ſee her agen thats certaine, what Ere comes ont, by your fauour Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: You'r welcome ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Know you the yong gentlewoman that went in lateley?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I haue beſt cauſe to know her, 'ime her mother ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Oh in good time, I like the gentlewoman well, a prety contriu'd beauty,

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: I, nature has done her part ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: But ſhe has one vncomely quality.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Whats that ſir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Sfoote ſhe's afraid of a man.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: A laſſe, impute that to her baſhfull ſpirit, ſhe's fearfull of her honour.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Of her honour? ſlid 'ime ſure I cannot get her maiden head with breathing vpon her, nor can ſhe looſe her honour in her tongue.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: True, and I haue often told her ſo, but what would you haue of a fooliſh virgine ſir, a wilfull virgine, I tell you ſir, I neede not haue beene in that ſolitarie eſtate that I am, had ſhe had grace and boldnes to haue put her ſelfe forward, alwaies timorſome, alwaies backward, ah that ſame peeuiſh honour of hers, has vndone her and me both good gentlemā: the ſuitors, the iewels, the ioynters that has beene offerd her, wee had beene made women for euer, but what was her faſhion? ſhe could not indure the ſight of a man for ſooth, but run and hole her ſelfe preſently, ſo choice of her honour, I am perſwaded, when ere ſhe has husband, ſhe wil eene be a preſident for all married wiues, how to direct their actions, and their liues.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Haue you not ſo much power with her, to commād her preſence.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee ſtraight what I can doe ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Would I might be hangd, if my loue do not ſtretch to her deeper and deeper, thoſe baſhfull maiden humors take me priſoner when their comes a reſtraint ont vpon fleſh, wee are alwaies moſt greedy vppont, & that makes your merchāts wife oftentimes pay ſo deare for a monthfull: giue me a woman as ſhe was made at firſt, ſimple of her ſelfe, without Sophiſtication, like this wench, I cannot abide them when they haue tricks, ſet ſpeeches & Artfull entertainments, you ſhall haue ſome ſo impudently aſpected, they will outcry the forehead of a man, make him bluſh firſt, & talke him into ſilence, & this is counted manly in a woman, it may hold ſo, ſure womanly it is not, no, If ere I loue, or any thing moue me,
T will be a womans ſimple modeſty.

div.stage: Enter Mother bringing in ſtriuingly the Curtezan.

sp.speaker: Curte.
sp.p: Pray let me go, why mother what doe you meane? I beſeech you mother? is this your conqueſt now? great glory tis to ouercome a pore and ſilly virgine.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: The wonder of our time ſits in that browe,
I nere beheld a perfit man till now.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Thou childiſh thing, more baſhfull then thour't wiſe,
Why doſt thou turne aſide, and drowne thine eies?
Looke fearefull foole, theres no tēptation nere thee,
Art not aſhamd that any fleſh ſhould feare thee,
sp.p: VVhy I durſt pawne my life the gentleman meanes no other but honeſt and pure loue to thee, how ſay you ſir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: By my faith not I Lady.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Harke you there? what think you now forſooth? what greeues your honour now?
Or what laſciuious breath intends to reare
Againſt that maiden Organ your chaſte care?
Are you reſolu'd now better of mens harts?
Their faiths and their affections, with you none,
Or at moſt, fewe whoſe tongues and minds are one.
Repent you now of your opinion paſt,
Men loue as purely as you can be chaſte: to her your ſelfe ſir,
The wayes broke before you, you haue the eaſier paſſage,

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: Feare not, come; erect thy happy graces in thy looke;
I am no curious wooer, but infaith
I loue thee honourably.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.p: How meane you that ſir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Sfoot as one loues a woman for a wife,

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Has the gentleman anſwered you, tro?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: I do confeſſe it truely to you both,
My eſtate is yet but ſickly, but I'ue a Grandſire
Will make me Lord of thouſands at his death.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: I know your Grandſire well; ſhe knowes him better.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why then you know no fiction; my ſtate then will be a long dayes iourney 'boue the waſt wench.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Nay daughter he ſayes true.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: And thou ſhalt often meaſure it in thy coache,
And with the wheels tract make a gridle for't.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Ah twilll be a merry iourny.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What iſt a match, if't be clap hands & lips;

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Tis done, ther's witneſſe on't.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why then mother I ſalute you.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Thanks ſweet ſonne;—Sonne Folliwit, come hither, if I might counſell thee, weele eene take her while the good moods vpon her, ſend for a Prieſt, and clapt vp within this hower.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: By my troth agreed mother.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Nor do's her wealth conſiſt all in her fleſh,
Tho beauty be enough wealth for a woman,
She brings a Dowry of three hundred pound with her.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Sfoote that will ſerue till my Grandſire dyes I warrant you, heele drop away at fall a'th leafe, if euer he reach to all Hollantide ile be hangd.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: O yes ſonne, hees a luſty old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Ah pox, hee's giuen to weomen; he keeps a queane at this preſent.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Do not tell my wife ont.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: That were needleſſe yfaith.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: He makes a great feaſt vpon the leauenth of this month, tueſday next, and you ſhall ſee Players there,—I haue one tricke more to put vpon him; my wife and your ſelfe ſhall goe thither before as my gueſts, and proue his entertainment, Ile meete you there at night, the ieſt will be here, that feaſt which he makes wil, vnknown to him ſerue fitly for our wedding dinner, we ſhall be royally furniſht, and get ſome charges by'te.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: An excellent courſe (yfaith) and a thrifty, why ſonne, me thinks you begin to thriue before y'are maried.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We ſhall thriue one day wench, and clep ynough? Between our hopes theres but a Grandſires puffe.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: So girle, here was a bird well caught.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: If euer, here: but what fo'rs Grandſire, twill ſcarce pleaſe him well.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Who couets fruit, nere cares from whence it fell,
Thou'ſt wedded youth and ſtrength, and wealth will fall:
Laſt thourt made honeſt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And thats worth 'em all.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter buſilie Sir Bounteous Progreſſe for the feaſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Haue a care blew-coates; beſtir your ſelfe Maſter Gumwater, caſt an eie intoth kitchin, orelooke the knaues a little, euery lack has his friend to day, this couſen and that couſen puts in for a diſh of meate, a man knowes not till he make a feaſt how many varlets he feedes, acquaintances ſwarme in euery corner, like flyes at Bartholmewtide that come vp with drouers, ſfoot I thinke they ſmell my kitchin ſeauen mile about maſter Shortrod and his ſweete bedfellow, yare very copiouſly welcome.

sp.speaker: Harebrain.
sp.p: Sir, heres an eſpeciall deere friend of ours, we were bold to make his way to your table.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Thankes for that boldneſſe euer, good Maſter
Shortrod, is this your friend ſir?

sp.speaker: Hareb.
sp.p: Both my wifes friend and mine ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why then compendeouſly ſir,—yare welcome.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: In Octauo I thanke you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Excellently retorted yfaith, hees welcome for's wit; I haue my ſorts of ſalutes, and know how to place em Courtly; walke in ſweet gentlemen, walke in, theres a good fire it'h Hall, you ſhall haue my ſweet company inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Harebraine.
sp.p: I good ſir Bounteous

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: You ſhall indeede gentlemen; how now, what newes brings thee in ſtumbling now?

sp.speaker: Semus.
sp.p: There are certaine Players come to towne ſir, and deſire to enterlude before your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Players? by the maſſe they are welcome, the'yle grace my entertainment well, but for certain players there thou lyeſt boy; they were neuer more vncertaine in their liues, now vp & now downe, they know not when to play, where to play, nor what to play, not when to play for fearful fools, where to play for Puritane fooles, nor what to play for criticall fooles—goe call em in,—how fitly the whorſons come vpo'th feaſt, troth I was een wiſhing for em,—oh welcome, welcome my friends.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: The month of May delights not in her flowers, More then we ioy in that ſweete ſight of yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Well acted a my credit, I perceiue hees your beſt Actor.

sp.speaker: Semus.
sp.p: He has greateſt ſhare ſir; and may liue of himſelfe ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: What what? put on your hat ſir, pray put on; go too, welth muſt be reſpected, let thoſe that haue leaſt fethers ſtand bare; and whoſe men are you I pray? nay keep on your hat ſtill.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We ſerue my Lord Owemuch ſir.

sp.speaker: S. Boun.
sp.p: My L. Owemuch, by my troth the welcomſt men aliue giue me all your hands at once, that honorable gentleman? hee lay at my houſe in a robbery once, and tooke all quietly, went away cheerfully. I made a very good feaſt for him; I neuer ſaw a man of honor beare things brauelier away, ſerue my L. Owemuch? welcome yfaith: ſome Baſtard for my Lords Players,— where be you boyes?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: They come along with the Waggon ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Good, good, and which is your Polititian amongſt you? now yfaith he that workes out Reſtraints, makes beſt legs at Court and has a ſuit made of purpoſe, for the companies buſines, which is he, come▪ be not afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I am he ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Art thou he? giue me thy hand, harke in thine eare, thou row leſt too faſt to gather ſo much moſſe as thy fellow there, champ vpon that, ah, and what play ſhall we haue my maſters?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A pleaſant witty Comedy ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I, I, I, a Comedy in any caſe, that I and my gueſts may laugh a little, whats the name out?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Tis cald the Slip.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: The Slip? By my troth a pretty name, and a glib one: go all and ſlip intoot, as faſt as you can couer a table for the players. Firſt take heed of a Lurcher, hee cu • s deep, hee will eate vp all from you. Some Shirry for my Lords players there. Sirra, why this will be a True feaſt, a right Miter ſupper, a play and all, more lights—I cald for light, heere come in two are light inough for a whole houſe yfaith. Dare the theefe looke me i'th face? O impudent times! go too, diſſemble it.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Bleſſe you ſir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Bount.
sp.p: O welcome, welcome, Theefe, Queane, and Bawd, welcome all three.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Nay heeres but two on's ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A my troth, I tooke her for a couple, I'de haue ſworne there had beene two faces there.

sp.speaker: Moth▪
sp.p: Not all vnder one hood ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun▪
sp.p: Yes faith would I, to ſee mine eies beare double.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: He make it hold ſir, my doughter is a couple, She was married yeſterday. Sir Boun. Buz.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Nay to no buzzard neither, a right Hauke When ere you know him.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Away, he cannot be but a Raſcal▪ walke in walke in, bould gueſts, that come vnfent for—poſt, I perceiue how
my Iewels went now, to grace her marriage.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Would you with me ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Ey, how hapt it wench, you put the ſlip vpon me,
Not three nights ſince? I name it gently to you,
I terme it neither Pilfer, Cheat, nor Sharke.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Y'ear paſt my reach.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I'me old and paſt your reach, very good; but you will not deny this I truſt.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: With a ſafe conſcience, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Yee? giue me thy hand, fare thee wel, I haue done with her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Giue me your hand, ſir, you nere yet begun with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Whew, whew? O audacious age.
She denies me and all, when on her fingers,
I ſpide the Ruby ſit, that do's betray her,
And bluſhes for her fact, well theres a time ſor't,
For al's too little now for entertainment.
Feaſt, mirth, I harmony, and the play to boote.
A Iouiall Seaſon. How now, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Euen vpon readineſſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Keepe you your hat on.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I haue a ſuit to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh cry you mercy, then you muſt ſtand bare.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We could do all to the life of action ſir, both for the credit of your worſhips houſe, and the grace of our Comedy.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun▪
sp.p: Cuds me, what elſe ſir?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: And for ſome defects (as the cuſtome is) we would be bold to require your worſhips aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why with all my heart, what iſt you want? ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: One's a chaine for a Iuſtices hat ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: VVhy here, here, here, here whoreſon, wil this ſerue your turne?

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: VVhat elſe lacke you?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: VVe ſhould vſe a ring with a ſtone int.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p:
Nay whoope, I haue giuen too many rings already, talke no more of rings I pray you, here, here, here, make this
Iewell ſerue for once.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Oh this will ſerue ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: What haue you all now?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: All now ſir—one y time is brought i'th middle of the play, and I would deſire your worſhips watch time.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: My watch, with all my heart, onely giue time a charge that he be not fidling with it.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: You ſhall nere ſee that ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Well now you are furniſhe ſir, make haſte away.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Ee'n as faſt as i can ſir,—Ile ſet my fellows going firſt, they muſt haue time and leaſure, or they'r dull elſe. He ſtay and ſpeake a prologue, yet o'retake e'm, I cannot haue conſcience yfaith to go away and ſpeake nere a word to e'm, my Grādſire has giuen me three ſhares here, ſure Ile do ſomewhat for e'm.

div.stage: Enter Sir Bounteous and all the Gueſts.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: More lights, more ſtooles, ſit ſit, the play begins.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Haue you players here Sir Bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: We haue e'm for you ſir, fine nimble Comedians, proper actors moſt of them.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Whoſe men I pray you ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Oh▪ there's their credit ſir, they ſerue an honorable popular Gentleman, eclipped my Lord Ow-much.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: My Lord Ow-much, he was in Ireland lately.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: O you nere knew any of the name but were great trauellers,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: How is the Comedy cald, Sir Bounteous?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Mary ſir, the Slip.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The Slip?

sp.speaker: Sir Bou.
sp.p: I, and here the prologue begins to ſlip in vpon's.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Tis ſo indeed Sir Boun.

sp.speaker: Folly▪
sp.l: We ſing of wand • ing knights, what them betyde,
Who nor in one place, nor one thing abide,
They're here now, & anon no ſcouts can reach em
Being euery man well horſt like a bold Beacham,
The Play which we preſent, no fault ſhall meere
But one, youle ſay tis ſhort, weele ſay tis ſweete:
Tis giuen much to dumb ſhowes, which ſome prayſe,
And like the Terme, delights much in delayes.
So to conclude, and giue the name her due,
The play being calld the Slip, I vaniſh too.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Excellently well acted and a nimble conceyt.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The Prologues prety yfaith.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: And went off well.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I thats the grace of all, when they go away well, ah-

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A my troth and I were not married, I could finde in my heart to fall in loue with that Player now, and ſend for him to a ſupper; I know ſome i'th towne that haue done as much, and there tooke ſuch a good conceypt of their parts into'th two-penny roome, that the Actors haue bin found ith morning in a leſſe compaſſe then their Stage, tho twere nere ſo full of gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: But, paſſion of me, where be theſe knaues, wil they not come away, me thinkes they ſtay very long.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: Oh you muſt beare a little ſir, they haue many ſhifts to run into.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Shifts call you em, they're horrible long things.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A pox of ſuch fortune the plots betrayd:

All will come out, yonder they come taken vpon ſuſpition, and brought back by a Conſtable, I was accurſt to hold ſociety with ſuch Cockſcombs, whats to be done? I ſhall be ſhamde for euer, my wife here and al, ah pox—by light happily thought vpon, the chayne▪ Inuention ſticke to me this once, and faile me euer hereafter: ſo, ſo,—

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Life I ſay, where be theſe Players, oh are you come, troth its time, I was een ſending for you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: How moodily he walkes, what playes he tro?

sp.speaker: Sir Bou.
sp.p: A, Iuſtice vpon my credit, I know by the chayn there.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Vnfortunate Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah—a—a—

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: In thy kin vnfortunate.
Here comes thy Nephew now vpon ſuſpition,
Brought by a Conſtable before thee, his vilde aſſociates with him,
But ſo diſguizde, none knowes him but my ſelfe,
Twice haue I ſet him free from officers ſangs,
And for his ſake, his fellowes: let him looke too't:
My conſcience will permit but one winke more.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Yee ſhall we take Iuſtice winking.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: For this time I haue be thought a meanes to worke thy
freedome, tho hazarding my ſelfe; ſhould the Law ceaze him,
Being kin to me, twould blenuſh much my name, No;
I'de rather leane to danger, then to ſhame.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun:
sp.p: A very expleate Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Thank you good neighbors, let me alone with em now.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Sfoote whoſe yonder?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.p: Dare he ſit there?
2. Follywit.
3. Captaine—puh—

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: How now Conſtable what newes with thee?

sp.speaker: Conſt▪
sp.p: May it pleaſe your worſhip ſir,—here are a company of auſpicious fellowes.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: To me; puh—turne to'th Iuſtice you whorſon hobby horſe, this is ſome new player now, they put all their fooles to the Conſtables part ſtill.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Whats the matter Conſtable, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I haue nothing to ſay to your worſhip—they were all riding a horſeback ant pleaſe your worſhip

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Yet agen: a pox of all Aſles ſtill, they could not ride a foot vnleſſe twere in a bawdy houſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: The Oftler told me they were all vnſtable fellows ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: VVhy ſure the fellow's drunke.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p:
VVe ſpide that weakeneſſe in him long agoe ſir, your worſhip muſt beare with him, the mans much oreſeene, onely in reſpect of his office wee obeyd him, both to appeare conformable to law, and cleare of all offence: for I proteſt ſir,
he found vs but a horſe backe:

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What he did?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.p: As I haue a ſoule, thats all, and all he can lay to vs.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Yfaith, you were not all riding away then.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.p: S'foot, being a horſebacke ſir, that muſt needs follow.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: VVhy true ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Well ſayd Iuſtice, he helps his kinſeman well.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: VVhy Sirra, do you vſe to bring Gentlemen before vs for riding away, what will you haue em ſtand ſtill when they're vp, like Smug vpo'th white horſe yonder? are your wits ſteept? He make you an example for all dizzy Conſtables, how they abuſe iuſtice, here bind him tot his chayre.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ha, bind him hoe?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: If you want cords, vſe garters.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Help, help, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.p: As faſt as we can ſir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Theeues, theeues.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A gag will help all this, keepe leſſe noiſē you knaue.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Oh helpe, reſcue the Conſtable — oh, O.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.l: VVhy la you who lets you now?
You may ride quietly, Ile ſee you to,
Take horſe my ſelfe. I haue nothing elſe to doe.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Oh,—oh—oh—

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha, by my troth the maddeſt piece of Iuſtice gentlemen, that euer was committed.

sp.speaker: Scort R.
sp.p: He be ſworne for the madneſſe on't ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I am deceiu'de, if this proue not a merry Comedy and a witty.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: A laſſe poore Conſtable, his mouth's open, and nere a wife word.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Faith he ſpeakes now een as many as he has done, he ſeemes wiſeſt when he gapes and ſayes nothing, ha ha;— he turnes and tells his tale to me like an aſſe, what haue I to do with their riding away, they may ride for me, thou whorſon Cockſcombe th • n; nay thou art well ynough ſeru'de yfaith,

sp.speaker: Maſt. Pae.
sp.p: But what followes all this while ſir, me thinkes ſome ſhould paſſe by before this time, & pitty the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Byth maſſe and you ſay true ſir,—goe ſirrah, ſtep in, I thinke they haue forgot themſelues, call the knaues away they'r in a wood I beleeue.—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hanke, the Conſtable ſayes I, they're in a wood,— ha, ha,—

sp.speaker: Nub.
sp.p: He thinkes long of the time sir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How now? when come they?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: A laſſe an't pleaſe your worſhip, ther's not one of them to be found ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Short. R.
sp.p: What ſaies the fellow?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Neither horſe nor man ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Body of me thou lieſt.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Not a haire of either ſir.

sp.speaker: Short. R.
sp.p: How now sir Bounteous.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Cheated and defeated, vngag that raſcall, Ile hang him for's fellowes, Ile make him bring em out.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Did not I tell your worſhip this before, brought em before you for ſuſpected perſons, Hayd em at townes end vpon warning giuen, made ſignes that my very iaw bone akes, your worſhip would not heare me, cald me Aſle, ſauing your worſhips preſence laught at me.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I begin to taſte it.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Giue me leaue, giue me leaue, why art not thou the Conſtable it'h Comedy?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ith comedy? why I am the conſtable i'th common wealth ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: I am guld yfaith, I am guld, when waſt thou choſe?

sp.speaker: Conſta▪
sp.p: On thurſday laſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: A pox go wit'ht, ther't goes.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: I ſeldome heard Ieſt match it.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Nor I yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Gentlemen ſhal I intreat a curteſy?

sp.speaker: Short▪
sp.p: What iſt ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Do not laugh at me ſeauen yeare hence.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: Wee ſhould betray and laugh at our owne folly then, for of my troth none heere but was deceiud int.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Faith thats ſome comfort yet, ha, ha, it was feately carried, troth I commend their wits, before our faces, make vs aſſes while we ſit ſtill, and onely laugh at our ſelues.

sp.speaker: M. Peni.
sp.p: Faith they were ſome counterfeit rogues ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Why they confeſſe ſo much them ſelues, they ſaide theyd play the ſlip, they ſhold be men of their words, I hope the Iuſtice will haue more conſcience yfaith, then to cary away a chaine of a hundred marke of that faſhion.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: What ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: I by my troth ſir, beſides a iewell, and a iewels fellowe, a good faire watch that hung about my neck ſir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Sfoote what did you meane ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Me thinkes my Lord Owemuches players ſhould not ſcorne me ſo yfaith they will come and bring all agen I know, puſh they will yfaith, but a ieaſt certainly.

div.stage: Enter Follywit in his owne ſhape, and all the rest,

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Pray Grandſire giue me your bleſſing?

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Who? Sonne Folliwit?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: This ſhowes like kneeling after the play, I praying for my Lord Owemuch and his good Counteſſe, our honourable Lady and miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Riſe richer by a bleſſing, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Thankes good grandſire, I was bold to bring thoſe gentlemen my friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Theyre all welcome, ſalute you that ſide, & ile welcome this ſide. Sir to begin with you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Maſter Follywit.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I am glad tis our fortune ſo happily to meete ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Nay then you know me not ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Sweete Miſtris Harebraine.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: You cannot be too bold ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Our mariage knowne?

sp.speaker: Curte.
sp.p: Not a word yet.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: The better.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p:
Faith ſonne would you had come ſooner with theſe
gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Why Grandſire?

sp.speaker: S. Bo.
sp.p: We had a play here.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: A play ſir, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Yes faith, a pox a'th Author.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Bles vs all, why were they ſuch vild ones ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: I am ſure villanous ones ſir.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Some rawe-ſimple fooles.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Nay bith maſſe theſe were enough for the euiſh knaues.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: What ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Which way came you gentlemen, you could not chooſe but meete em.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: We met a company with hampers after em.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: Oh thoſe were they, thoſe were they, a pox hamper em.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Bleſſe vs all agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: They haue hamperd me finely ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Howe ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.p: How ſir, I lent the raſcals properties to furniſh out their play, a chaine, a iewell, and a watch, & they watcht their time, and rid quite away with em.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Are they ſuch creatures.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Hearke, hearke gentlemen, by this light the watch rings alarum in his pocket, thers my watch come agen, or the very Coſen German toot, whoſe iſt, whoſe iſt? by'th maſſe tis he, haſt thou one ſonne? prethee beſtow it vpon thy Grandſire, I now looke for mine agen yfaith, nay come with a good wil or not at all. Ile giue thee a better thing a peece, a peece gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Great or ſmall,

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: At once I haue drawne chaine, iewell, watch & all.

sp.speaker: Maſt. Penit.
sp.p: By my faith you haue a fortunate hand ſir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Nay all to come at once.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.p: A vengeance of this ſoolecy.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Haue I ſcape the Conſtable to be brought in by the watch?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: O deſtiny, haue I married a Theefe mother?

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.p: Comfort thy ſelfe, thou art before hand with him daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Why ſon, why gentlemen, how long haue you bin my Lord Ow-much his ſeruants yfaith?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Faith Grandſire, ſhall I be true to you?

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: I thinke tis time, thouſt beene a theeſe already.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: I knowing the day of your feaſt, & the natural inclination you haue to pleaſure and paſtime, preſumde vpon your patience for a ieſt as well to prolong your daies as—

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Whoop, why then you tooke my chaine along with you to prolong my daies did you?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Not ſo neither ſir & that you may be ſeriouſly aſſured of my herafter ſtableneſſe of life, I have took another courſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Tooke a wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: A wife? ſfoot, what is ſhe for a foole would marry thee a madman? when was the wedding kept in Bedlam?

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: Shees both a gentlewoman and a virgin.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Stop there, ſtop there, would I might ſee her.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: You haue your wiſh, ſhees here.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha, this makes amends for all.

sp.speaker: Folly.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.p: Captain do you heare? is ſhe your wife in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.p: Nothing but pitty you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Speake ſonne iſt true?
Can you gull vs, and let a queane gull you.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: What I haue bin is paſt, be that forgiuen,
And haue a ſoule true both to thee and heauen.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.p: Iſt come about, tricks are repaid I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir Bo.
sp.l: The beſt is ſirrah you pledge none but me
And ſince I drinke the top, take her and harke,
I ſpice the bottome with a thouſand marke.

sp.speaker: Follie.
sp.l: By my troth, ſhe is as good a cup of Nectar, as amy
Batchelor needs to ſip at.
Tut giue me gold, it makes amends for vice,
Maydes without coine, are candles without ſpice.

sp.speaker: Sir Boun.
sp.l: Come gentlemen toth feaſt, let not time waſte,
We haue pleaſd our eare, now let vs pleaſe our taſte
Who liues by cunning marke it, his fates caſt,
When he has guld all, then is himſelfe the laſt.
